title: how new zealand eliminated coronavirus british university model uk lockdown
story: NEW Zealands go hard and go early battle plan has helped it smash coronavirus after using a British university model.The country of five million has sent the killer bug packing thanks to strong leadership, huge public support, and taking notice of Imperial College Londons influential scientic paper - which also prodded the UK into lockdown.New Zealand set itself an ambitious goal of eliminating the bug altogether, and experts believe the country could pull it off.Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern, , took bold steps, putting the country under a strict lockdown in late March, when only about  people had tested positive for the new virus. Her motto was: “Go hard and go early.”Ardern added: “We have the opportunity to do something no other country has achieved: elimination of the virus.“But it will continue to need a team of five million behind it.”Her tough stance echoed measures outlined in a groundbreaking Imperial College report, which gave results of epidemiologicial modelling in the absence of a Covid- vaccine.The college looked into the likely outcome of ious public health measures and found that without strict intervention, the bug could infect  per cent of the population.These included mitigation - slowing but not stopping the spread - and suppression, which aims to reverse the viruss growth.And today, New Zealand slackened its grip on its Covid- rules, allowing about , people toto work.Restaurants, including McDonalds, were able to offer diners takeaway meals, while construction, manufacturing and forestry businesses are allowed to operate under less stringent measures.New Zealand on Tuesday recorded just three new cases of the coronavirus, bringing its total to ,. There have been  deaths.Imperial College said that suppression, while successful in China and South Korea, carries with it enormous social and economic costs which may have signicant impact on health and wellbeing in the short and longer-term. Mitigation will never be able to completely protect those at risk from severe disease or death and the resulting mortality may therefore still be high. Instead we focus on feasibility.The college concluded that suppression is the only viable strategy at the current time, but the social and economic effects of the measures which are needed to achieve this policy goal will be profound.Our results suggest that population-wide social distancing applied to the population as a whole would have the largest impact.[This] in combination with other interventions – home isolation of cases and school and university closure – has the potential to suppress transmission below the threshold of R required to rapidly reduce case incidence.This R rating means the disease spreads at a stable rate, as one infected person is assumed to pass the bug on to just one other person.The college warned that doing anything less would result in hospitals being over-burdened with Covid- cases.So, rather than trying to flatten the curve by focusing on one major peak of infections, New Zealand has combated the disease by managing smaller outbreaks.Newsroom in New Zealand explains that the country no longer plans to manage the pandemic as a single wave, but to instead repeatedly snap stringent measures into place and reduce Covid- to a series of smaller waves.This change in attack was put down to Imperials groundbreaking scientic paper.Director-General of Health Ashley Bloomfield said: Our approach - and this is what successful countries have been doing - is you want to have a series of small peaks over a longer period of time.“And you amply up quite stringent controls to ensure that you dont exceed your health system capacity.Then as it goes down again, you can ease those and be prepared to ramp them up again.Aside from the science, Arderns leadership has won praise across the globe, for her empathetic and transparent approach.She, her ministers and public sector leaders have taken a  per cent pay cut for the next six months.Hours after New Zealand imposed a nationwide lockdown at the end of March, she took to Facebook, livestreaming in a sweater from bed, to “check in” on citizens and tell them of the day’s events.She said: “I thought I would jump online quickly and check in with everyone... as we all prepare to hunker down for a few weeks.A viewer posted in response: “This feels like the comfort of being tucked into bed at night by my mum. “Thanks for checking in with us.”And indeed the PM is a mum - she has also talked about spending time with family, and struggling with toilet training her daughter, who turns two in June.Dr Suze Wilson, leadership researcher at Massey Business School, in Palmerston North, said: Ardern is offering us a masterclass in crisis leadership.The PM has made clear the dangers we face, challenged us to make change and allowed space for concerns to be voiced so that they can addressed.She has regulated distress by providing a transparent framework for decision-making – the alert level framework – that allows people to make sense of what is happening and why.New Zealand has downgraded its alert level from four - complete lockdown - to three, which allows more freedom.Its expected to eventually wind its way down to level one, prepare, which means there will be no restrictions on gatherings.Minister of Civil Defence Peeni Henare said: “Since we went into lockdown most New Zealanders have done the right thing by following the rules and staying home. Getting this far has required a collective effort and we should be enormously proud of what we have achieved.New Zealands government also helped Kiwis to financially cope with the pandemic, during weeks of lockdown.Nearly  billion was allocated through the wage subsidy to protect the jobs of over a million working New Zealanders and keep them connected to their employers during the lockdown.Changes to the business tax system worth . billion helped boost cashflow, encouraged investment, and supported working from home.The Government also announced a suite of initiatives valued at  million, developed with the hard-hit media industry to help it get through the Covid- pandemic - and the severe drop in advertising revenue.And of course they tackled the issue of personal protective equipment early on - after its first case was reported on February .Minister for Health, Dr David Clark said on March : “Our frontline health care workers are doing incredibly important work on behalf of all New Zealanders. It’s vital they have access to the gear they need to stay safe.“Over the next month, the Ministry of Health will be supplying four million masks to the health sector and a further four million masks to non-health sector essential workers.“Face masks and other PPE are vital tools for our doctors, nurses and midwives, and other essential workers at this time.“We currently have more than  million masks in the national reserve held by the Ministry of Health and another . million held... with more on order from local and overseas manufacturers.Geography has also helped New Zealand, and with just five million people spread across an area the size of Britain, the cities aren’t overly crowded.Helen Petousis-Harris, a vaccine expert at the University of Auckland, said the country had managed to avoid the confusion and half-measures that have hampered the response in many other places.She said: “New Zealand got everything right.“Decisive action, with strong leadership and very clear communications to everybody.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: surge sti cases coronavirus halts clinics cervical screenings
story: CUTBACKS to sexual health services amid the coronavirus pandemic could cause a surge in STI cases in the UK, doctors are warning.STI clinics and cervical screenings have been put on hold across the country due to staff being deployed to other parts of hospitals to help with the Covid- outbreak.However, experts are now warning that the NHS will have to deal with a massive STI problem once the pandemic is over.And they say sexual health services have been “rolled back” by decades amid coronavirus upheaval.Dr Sarah Jarvis, GP and Clinical Director of Patientaccess,told The Sun Online: For men and women who are infected, there is no doubt that services have been reduced.It is easier to get treatment in some parts of the country than others. This could lead to delays which can cause serious health problems, especially for conditions like chlamydia.Tracey Forsyth, lead contraceptive nurse at British Pregnancy Advisory Service, also revealed that women are routinely telling her they are struggling to access sexual health services.She told The Independent: It is very dficult to access contraception, sexual health and have smears at the moment. There were lots of cuts to services before this.We have rolled the clock back with sexual health by decades due to coronavirus and cuts.Ms Forsyth added: Places are worrying we will have a massive STI problem at the end of Covid-.Most people dont experience any symptoms, and dont realise they are infected.Symptoms can include pain or a burning sensation during sex, and an unusual discharge.Women might also experience pain in the lower abdomen during or after sex, and bleeding after sex.In men, chlamydia can also cause a pain or tenderness in the testicles.. HPVHuman papilloma virus , which causes genital warts, is the second most common STI here in Britain.The warts are usually painful, but may be itchy or red. Occasionally, they cause bleeding.HPV is spread by skin-to-skin contact, so you can catch it evenyou havent had penetrative sex - and condoms DONT provide complete protection.. GonorrhoeaGonorrhoea is a bacterial STI - which often has no symptoms.Symptoms include pain or a burning sensation during sex, and an unusual discharge.Less common symptoms in women include pain in the lower gut and bleeding between periods or after sex.In men, gonorrhoea can cause swelling in the foreskin and, in rare cases, pain in the testicles.. HerpesGenital herpes in a common infection caused by HSV virus, which also causes cold sores.The symptoms can develop a few days after contact and include small, painful blisters which itch or tingle - and can make it dficult to urinate.. SyphillisSyphilis is bacterial infection which causes painless - but highly infectious - sores on the genitals and around the mouth.Symptoms for the second stage of syphilis include a rash, flu-like illness and patchy hair loss - which will last for a few weeks.In the third stage, which occurs after several years, people with syphilis may experience heart problems, paralysis and blindness.Ms Forsyth, whose contraceptive team speaks to around  women a week via the phone, said disruption to STI treatment is a problem for both men and women and was a “timely public health issue”.People who have chlamydia and gonorrhoea, and the people they have had sex with, need to be treated, she added.And Ms Forsyth warned that the cuts to sexual health services could have an even more detrimental effect on womens health - with chlamydia having a longer-term risk of pelvic inflammatory disease, which can cause infertility.On top of this, women are concerned about not being able to get smear tests, which help to pick up early signs of cell changes in the cervix that can turn into cancer.Kate Sanger, the spokesperson for charity Jo’s Cervical Cancer Trust, said the guidance from NHS England is to try to continue providing cervical screenings.But we know in some parts of the country, they have stopped sending out invitations for screenings or postponed them for the foreseeable future, she added.Provision is patchy. While there are some women who will want to go, some won’t be able to go because they are self-isolating.Sexual health charities urged the Government to tackle the rising number of STIs in the UK ahead of the coronavirus outbreak.A report by the Terrence Higgins Trust and British Association for Sexual Health  HIVreleased in February drew attention to the “unacceptably high” STI rates with a diagnosis every  seconds on average.In , there were , new diagnoses of STIs, which is an increase of five per cent from the year before.Despite this, Dr John McSorley, BASHH President, says they have seen a reduction in sexually transmitted infections diagnosed in clinics in the past month during lockdown.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.He told The Sun Online: The overwhelming majority of the UK population have done everything they can to save lives and protect the NHS by staying at home.We have seen a reduction in sexually transmitted infections diagnosed in clinics in the past month, and although some of this may be due to inability to test, it probably reflects less new infections.The last month or so has not been normal. As any lockdown is relaxed, we fully expect the UK populations sexual behaviour toto normal.It is true, the UK entered into lockdown against a backdrop of some of the highest numbers of some sexually transmitted infections especially for gonorrhoea and syphilis. Cases of syphilis are at levels not seen since World War Two. It is important that the Government fully supports ongoing open access to excellent sexual health services for everyone in the UK as we inch our way back towards normality.A happy healthy and fulfilling sex le is a really important cheap and cheerful way of putting a smile back on everyone’s face as summer approaches.If you think you may have an STI, the most important thing is to get tested and get medical advice quickly so you can start treatment.Doctors say you should call your GP or sexual health clinic - or the NHS says self-test kits for STIs are available online.If youre buying a self-test kit online, its important to be wary of the claims they make, as they may be misleading.Before using one, make sure the kit is sealed, without any damage to the packaging, and is within its expiry date.Check that the instructions for use are clear and easy to follow.You should also make sure it has a CE quality assurance mark - this means that, provided you use it correctly, the kit will work properly and is safe.If you think you need to see a doctor in an emergency, AE departments are still open, and doctors are urging people not to avoid seeking help in an emergency due to coronavirus fears.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gloves counted each in official figures
story: Downing Street confirmed earlier that gloves can be counted as one, two, or four in a spiralling row over personal protective equipment.It came as part of a BBC Panorama documentary last night which said some items were counted inidually, rather than as a pair.That could make the PPE numbers for the equipment dished out appear higher than they actually were.But some healthcare professionals came out to say that many gloves were normally counted inidually.Billions of bits of protective equipment has been sent out since the pandemic began, but doctors and NHS staff in some places are still saying they are short.The Government today admitted dferent gloves were counted in dferent ways.It’s not even that simple, The Prime Ministers spokesperson said.Gloves are counted dferently depending on clinical settings, sometimes they’re single, sometimes pairs and sometimes fours for clinical reasons.It is not correct to say they’re counted inidually, they’re counted in a number of dferent ways.Meanwhile, the BBC report also found key items of PPE were not included in the Governments pandemic stockpile when coronavirus reached the UK.BBC Panorama reported that gowns, visors, swabs and body bags were left out of the stockpile when it was set up in . story: It had been suggested people who survive the virus could exit the lockdown first as they may have developed natural immunity – known as antibodies.But Professor Danny Altmann admitted scientists “haven’t got the foggiest” about whether Covid survivors are actually protected from reinfection.The immunology expert said antibodies might not actually kill the bug off for good.It could cling on secretly in a person’s gut, according to evidence seen by ministers.And he warned he would be “terribly worried” about lting the lockdown without more information about the nation’s immunity levels.Prof Altmann, from Imperial College, told MPs “What an antibody test tells you is that you have met the virus – you have had exposure to the virus and it triggered an immune response.“It offers you no conclusion whatsoever about whether you will be immune to it next time you meet it.”He said scientists “haven’t got the foggiest notion of” whether someone who has had Covid becomes immune to it.Britain is in a global race to try to find an antibody test which can work on iniduals and reliably saythey have had the virus.Boris Johnson has said the tests could be a “game changer”.But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. title: pubs pint limit lockdown
story: Professor Eyal Winter suggested Brits were starving for pubs, and the Government would bring in a drink limit to help them stay safe.Speaking to , the Lancaster University academic insisted social distancing would be requiredpubs reopen.He is advising the Government on how to ease the coronavirus restrictions, and speaks with the Cabinet Office’s behavioural science group.Pubs have been shut since the UK went into lockdown on March , but the economist suggested landlords and shop owners could be asked to enforce new rules.He suggested landlords could ration how much beer they serve to two or three pints.Customers would then be politely told to go home.He said: “People are starving for pubs. They are an important part of British culture.“One of the most important things is to have a programme, to say, ‘in two weeks we will do such and such’.“You need to make the rules crystal clear, and to explain to the public the rationale behind each one of them.”The academic, who is also professor at the Hebrew University’s centre for the study of rationality, insisted things would get back to normal.He added: “It will take a lot of time to move back to January . But we will get there.”The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. title: sunshine less vulnerable coronavirus
story: JUST ten minutes of sunshine a day can make you less vulnerable to coronavirus, a doctor has claimed. Aussie health expert Dr Rachel Neale said that having low levels of vitamin D, which the skin produces when exposed to sunlight, increases vulnerability to the virus.Her advice comes just days after Public Health England urged Brits to take vitamin D supplements during coronavirus lockdown.Skin cancer researcher Dr Neale claimed vitamin D is essentially in curbing the symptoms of the deadly bug.Now, more than ever, is not the time to be vitamin D deficient, Dr Neale told The Australian.It would make sense that being vitamin D deficient would increase the risk of having symptomatic Covid- and potentially having worse symptoms.And thats because vitamin D seems to have important effects on the immune system.Last year, Dr Neale and a team of researchers claimed that vitamin D supplementation reduced the risk of acute respiratory infections, which is what Covid- falls under.According to their study of , patients, people with low levels of vitamin D are almost twice as likely as those with high levels of vitamin D of developing acute respiratory infections.On top of this, they claimed people with vitamin D deficiencies were more likely to be sicker for longer.Vitamin D is thought to fend off respiratory infections by boosting antibiotic-like substances in the lungs.Dr Neale revealed that she sits in the sun in Brisbane, Australia, for for five to ten minutes everyday to trigger her bodys production of vitamin D.The doctor does not take vitamin D tablets as she believes time in the sun provides more benefits - but accepts they are useful for people who cant leave their home.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.Just last week, health chiefs issued an update on the Public Health England website saying that during coronavirus lockdown, Brits should take a vitamin D supplement to compensate for the lack of sunshine.It said: Consider taking ten micrograms of vitamin D a day to keep your bones and muscles healthy.This is because you may not be getting enough vitamin D from sunlightyou’re indoors most of the day.You can buy vitamin D supplements at most pharmacies and supermarkets. Do not buy more than you need.Despite this, Public Health England say that there is currently no evidence that he p-a-pill “sunshine vitamin” reduces the risk of coronavirus.Commenting on the advice, Dr Alison Tedstone, chief nutritionist at PHE said: With the nation staying in to save lives and protect the NHS, many people are spending more time indoors and may not get all the vitamin D they need from sunlight.To protect their bone and muscle health, they should consider taking a daily supplement containing  micrograms of vitamin D - there is no sufficient evidence to support recommending vitamin D for reducing the risk of Covid-.PHE has previously recommended everyone should take a ten microgram supplement of vitamin D during the autumn and winter months, thereports.Although they are very safe, taking more than the recommended amount every day can be dangerous in the long run.Below are the recommended daily doses depending on age:More sunshine in spring and summer meant this was no longer necessary for most people but this has been updated to recommend everyone should continue taking it.Scientists will soon be investigating whether vitamin D can help coronavirus patients fight coronavirus.A research team from the University of Granada in Spain is to run a ten-week trial involving  Covid- patients to establishtaking the sunshine vitamin can help fight the illness.The scientists say a lack of vitamin D in calves is thought to have been the main cause of bovine coronavirus infections in the past.The study aims to investigate whether the “use of vitamin D induces signicant improvements of health... as well as preventing health deterioration”.Dr Jenna Macciochi, of the University of Sussex, said: “If you are deficient in vitamin D, you are three to four times more likely to catch a cold.“It therefore makes sense a viral respiratory infection like Covid- would be worseyou were vitamin D-deficient.”Vitamin D is vital to help your body absorb calcium as well as strengthening the immune system.It is found in:Studies show around one in five adults are thought to be lacking in the “sunshine vitamin”, but  per cent ignore Government prompts to take a supplement.The body makes vitamin D when exposed to sunlight – so those in cooler and less sunny climates, like the UK, have a higher risk of being vitamin D deficient.People with darker skin need more sunlight than those with pale skin to generate enough vitamin D.The most obvious places to buy vitamin D tablets and supplements is at pharmacies and supermarkets.Get Britains best-selling story: ANYONE who leaves home to go to work can now be tested for coronavirus, Matt Hancock revealed today.The Health Secretary expanded testing for Covid- to make sure around  million more people more can get checked - under radical plans to get the country moving again.Mr Hancock also confirmed that testing has been expanded to include:Speaking at todays press briefing, Mr Hancock said: Anyone living or working in care homes can now get access to a test whether they have symptoms or not.And we now have the capacity to go further still. From now, we will be making testing available to all over s and their households with symptoms and workers who have to leave home to go to work and members of their households who have symptoms.From construction workers to emergency plumbers, from research scientists to those in manufacturing, the expansion of access to testing will protect the most vulnerable and help keep people safe.Its possible because weve expanded capacity for testing thus far.The five ways iniduals can get a test are:The Health Secretary said as part of the plans to increase testing capacity - to hit the ,-day target by the end of April - more tests would be available.Home testing will be increased from , a day to , by this Friday, while  new mobile testing sites staffed by the Army are due to open by the end of the week - taking the total to .He said: At the start of the month we set a goal of , tests a day - every day we are ramping this up and we are on track to meet that goal. There are now  drive thrus,  going live this week.For people who cant get to the tests we are expanding home tests to get it to them.We will be expanding home from , last Friday to , a day this Friday.By the end of the week we plan to have over  mobile testing units deployed.All of this has led to an increase in daily test in capacity of ,.Mr Hancock also confirmed during the press briefing that from now on, the Department of Health will report deaths in hospital, care homes and the community daily - despite the fact previously its just been hospital deaths.The Department of Health and Social Care are currently supporting  NHS trusts with satellite test sites for their staff .Last week Mr Hancock announced around ten million key workers from the NHS and care staff to police officers, firefighters, journalists and supermarket staff would be able to get tests through a new online portalthey needed one.But yesterday, home tests kits online were unavailable only an hour after new slots were released.It was the fourth day in a row sick Brits were unable to get a hold of the tests they need through the portal., home testing kits were ordered yesterday through the site.Until then, only limited numbers of Brits such as patients, health and care workers and some key public sector staff were eligible for a test. Brits without a car will be offered a home test, including swabs and instructions – with , kits sent out daily before the scheme is ramped up.They will be delivered by Amazon within  hours, before being collected the next day by Royal Mail.All those tested will get their results by text within  hours of having their swab taken.The Department of Health and Social Care has launched a new web portal for employers and self-referral for key workers and their families.Anyone can checkthey are eligible and where they can get a test at www.gov.uk coronavirus.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. title: british airways 12000 workers redundant
story: The airline, which employs , people, has been crippled by the coronavirus crisis which has caused a global collapse in passenger numbers.Nine out of  flights have been grounded since the UK went into lockdown.IAG announced the planned job cuts as it revealed revenues plunged  per cent in the first quarter of this year.It said it will take several years until demand for air travel s to  levels.In a letter to staff, BA chief executive Alex Cruz wrote: In the last few weeks, the outlook for the aviation industry has worsened further and we must take action now.We are a strong, well-managed business that has faced into, and overcome, many crises in our hundred-year history.We must overcome this crisis ourselves, too.There is no Government bailout standing by for BA and we cannot expect the taxpayer to offset salaries indefinitely.He went on: We will see some airlines go out of business.Around , pilots and , cabin crew work for BA.IAG did not provide a breakdown of how many people in what roles could be made redundant.In a statement, IAG said: In light of the impact of Covid- on current operations and the expectation that the recovery of passenger demand to  levels will take several years, British Airways is formally notying its trade unions about a proposed restructuring and redundancy programme.The proposals remain subject to consultation but it is likely that they will affect most of British Airways employees and may result in the redundancy of up to , of them.As previously announced, British Airways has availed itself of the UKs Covid- job retention scheme and furloughed , employees in April.Last week Which  revealed travel firms and airlines, including British Airways, were breaking the law by delaying refunds for trips cancelled due to the pandemic.Some firms are refusing to provide refunds in a breach of their legal obligations, while others are offering vouchers or credit instead.Passengers are due a refund within seven daysa flight title: kim jong un yacht wonsan
story: The North Korean dictator has not been seen in public since April  sparking reports he is gravely ill or even dead.According to satellite imagery by NK Pro, the boats made unusual moves around April  during the rogue states last missile test.This would suggest that Kim was in the area as there is a high correlation between luxury vessel movements in Wonsan and the leaders presence, the outlet claims.Further analysis shows similar boat movements at a villa in Wonsan and a nearby island close to the Kalma peninsula which align with the despots appearances in previous summers including last year.NK Pro has successfully confirmed Kims presence in and around Wonsan, which is in the east of the country, on  of the last  occasions he has visited since .The outlets sister site NK News claims the main -metre leisure boat in the images was the same vessel used during a visit by NBA basketball star Dennis Rodman.As millions of North Koreans starve, the despot’s guests at Wonsan dine on the finest imported food like lobsters, scallops and French cheeses and wash it down with bottles of champagne.Former Chicago Bulls star Rodman – who has struck up a bizarre friendship with the dictator – talked about the party resort comparing it to Spanish island Ibiza.He said: “Its like going to Hawaii or Ibiza, but hes the only one that lives there.“Hes got  to  people around him all the time - just normal people, drinking cocktails and laughing the whole time.If you drink a bottle of tequila, its the best tequila.Everything you want, he has the best.Guests of Kim are given rooms decorated with imported antique furniture, paintings and tapestries.His seaside party pad – close to the port of Wonson – has its own marina and secluded bays patrolled  hours a day by heavily armed troops.Jet skis, yachts and speed boats are moored under covers at the marina.The North Korean leaders so-called pleasure train turned up last week in Wonsan after the despot vanished from the public eye.The luxury locomotive was seen in satellite images – and will now surely be tracked by Western spy agencies eager for news on his condition after claims he was dead.The train is understood to carry Kim’s armoured Mercedes, sometimes accompanied by another armoured vehicle carrying his personal mobile toilet.The -carriage beast boasts a lounge lined with pink leather sofas, a modern conference room and office with satellite TV, and a galley to rustle up the finest cuisine.And it is reported to be packed with beautul “lady conductors” – taken from the ranks of Kim’s hand-picked “Pleasure Brigade”.The tubby tyrant is understood to have launched a recruitment drive for “tall and beautul” girls in .The woman are said to be examined by a doctor to checkthey are still virgins.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kim jong un cannot stand up or walk
story: The dictator has not been seen in public since April  sparking reports he has died or is in a vegetative state following heart surgery.Kim failed to attend the annual birthday celebrations of his grandfather Kim il-sung, the revered founder of North Korea, on April .Thae Yong-ho, an ex-diplomat for the rogue state who is now a South Korean politician, says the leaders absence from the celebrations – known as the Day of the Sun - prove he is ill or injured.He told CNN: “Kim Jong Un is not only the leader of North Korea, but he is the grandson of Kim Il-sung ... to North Korean eyes it is really abnormal.Im not quite sure whether he really had some surgery or whatever, but one thing is clear... he cannot stand up by himself or walk properly.”While the high-level defector did not provide any supporting evidence, Kim is known to struggle with his weight reportedly tipping the scales at up to  stone.The -year-old despot is known for his unhealthy lestyle including his love of rich foods, booze and cigarettes.There have been reports in Japan and Hong Kong that Kim died or is brain dead after a botched heart operation.However, Thae says these claims are most likely incorrect give the incredible secrecy surrounding Kim Jong-un.He said: “The only people who can confirm his real condition might be Kim Jong Uns we or his sister, or his close aides.Those rumors of where he is now,whether he has any surgery, I dont think that is really based on the facts.”Thae pointed to the death of Kims father Kim Jong-il which was announced  hours after it happened in .In fact, the countrys then-Foreign Minister was told about the dictators death only an hour before it was officially announced, he said.Reports from South Korea claim that Kim underwent heart surgery on April  and was seriously ill.The countrys intelligence services detected “nothing to confirm the rumours, officials said, and ally China also denied he was gravely ill.But Japanese newspaper Shukan Gendai last week reported Kim had been left in a vegetative state by the bungled operation.Unconfirmed reports claimed the North Korean leader was taken to hospital after clutching his chest and falling to the ground while out in the countryside.He had a procedure to insert a stent which went wrong because the terried surgeons hands were shaking, it was claimed.It comes after Shijian Xingzou, vice director of Beijing-backed broadcaster Hong Kong Satellite Television, fuelled online rumours the tyrant was already dead.She said on Chinese social media site Weibo that a very solid source had told her that Kim had died but did not give any further details.Reports suggested he had been staying at an exclusive private villa on the countrys east coast after a number of people around him tested positive for coronavirus.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMillions of key workers and their households are now eligible for a coronavirus  test under an expansion of the programme announced by the government. Health Secretary Matt Hancock set out his plans for easier, faster and simpler testing so more people can access a Covid- test to tellthey currently have the virus. At the daily Downing Street briefing, Mr Hancock said the capacity for carrying out tests was now ahead of our plans, with the ability to carry out more than , tests a day. But he still faces a huge hurdle to climb to reach his , target - almost double current levels - in a weekaposs time. Because capacity has now increased so substantially, we are now able to expand who can get the tests, he said.Our ultimate goal is that everyone who could benefit from a test gets a test. Mr Hancock said: Itaposs all part of getting Britain back on her feet. But you may have to drive for a -minute round trip to get a test and there could be heavy demand on new kits to be posted to your home. Hereaposs who is eligible and how the system will work. Who is eligible for a test  As the UK extends its testing capacity a growing list of people are eligible to be tested. So in addition to any worker who the government deems as essential, and any members of their family, the any worker who has to leave their home is now also eligible to be tested. This includes thousands of construction workers, delivery drivers and others. In the UK there are around million people classed as essential workers but their households will also be eligible under the scheme. NHS staff and care home workers are already being referred for testing by their workplaces. And they will now be able be tested eventhey are not showing symptoms. But who is essential  It it the same list of occupations used by the government to determine whether or not you can continue to send your children to school during lockdown. Key workers on the list are the same as those for access to schools, and include NHS and social care workers, police officers, teachers, social workers, those in the justice system, undertakers, some in local government, supermarket and food production workers, journalists, transport workers and some people in utilities and IT. A full list is below or on this web page. How sick do you have to be   You need to show symptoms in order to be tested, unless you work in a care home of for the NHS. The main two are a new and persistent dry cough and a temperature. But other people who have tested positive for covid- include losing taste and a sense of smell.    It will showyou currently have Covid-. This is useful to proveyour symptoms are actually the virus. It does not showyouaposve had Covid- in the past. It will help people work out when they and their household members canto work safely. Where do I log on to book a test  Visit the governmentaposs web page. Where do I go to get tested     The first port of call is a drive-through testing centre -  of which are currently open, with  promised by the end of April. The government expects you to be able to drive for up to  minutes from your home to get to a drive-through site, leaving some with potentially a -minute round trip. WhatI canapost drive     For those who donapost live near enough to a testing site or canapost drive there are other options. The government has pledged that Royal Mail and Amazon will deliver home testing kits for the first time from Friday. The availability of these will be limited at first, at just , per day. Officials hope for this to scale up to , a day by the end of April. What about other ways of getting tested  Meanwhile apossatelliteapos test kits are also being sent directly to care homes to enable residents with symptoms to be tested. And the Army is helping set up mobile testing units which will travel the country to places like care homes, police stations and prisons. Itaposs not clear how these will help workers without a mobile unit or satellite kit at their place of work. How long will I wait for results     Test results from the drive-through sites will be sent out by text within  hours, the government says. For home delivery tests, the waiting time is  hours. Itaposs not clear how quickly a test will be booked in once youaposve asked for it - presumably it depends on demand. Why are essential workers getting tested  The aim is simple - to ensure they can get back to work. Because the test showsyou currently have Covid-, it also can given an indication that your cough is just a  alarm. So people whoaposve been self-isolating to protect others due to a mild cough can get back on the front line. Whataposs it like getting the test   The test involves taking a swab  of the nose and throat - and it goes back pretty far, so be prepared. A single swab is used to collect a liquid sample from the back of your throat and your nose. This swab is then placed into a sample tube and securely packaged, where it is sent to the lab for testing. Depending on where you get tested, you will either have a clinician take your swab or be asked to do it yourself.

She warned that the current system had left families at the mercy of cancelled flights, airline strikes, extortionate prices, domestic lockdowns and chaotic booking systems. She added: It is now five weeks since lockdown began in the UK, and over three months since the World Health Organisation declared this a global health emergency. While I note your department does not have an estimate of the number of British citizens still stranded overseas, my office is currently in contact with , British citizens stranded in  dferent countries and it is estimated there are hundreds of thousands of British citizens who remain stranded overseas. The Shadow Foreign Secretary said that around the world, many governments have been far more successful than we have. For example, it has been almost two weeks since Germany repatriated the last of its , citizens from New Zealand using twenty-six charter flights arranged by their government. By contrast only  Britons have ed from the country and the first UK charter flight from New Zealand only departed this week, she added. Some estimates put the number of Brits struggling to get home as high  as ,. Countries like France and Germany relied much more heavily on chartered flights - meaning citizens got home quicker but at a much higher cost. The Government has defended its policies focus on using commercial flights to get Brits home. At the end of March, Dominic Raab said that he had struck as £ million deal with British airlines to help those still stranded around the world.  But last week, the top civil servant at the Foreign Office told MPs that while many Brits were now home it would take several weeks for the government to help those looking toto the UK. Sir Simon McDonald, who is Head of the Diplomatic Service, told MPs that an estimated . million UK citizens were abroad at the time of the crisis and that . million were now home thanks to mostly commercial flights. He said the strategy of relying on airlines where they could was the best use of taxpayers cash and helped the government direct support.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe UK has now been under lockdown for more than a month - and thereaposs no sign it will stop soon. But with other European countries beginning to relax their rules, calls are growing for the government to spell out how it will eventually be relaxed. Tory MPs have piled on pressure to save the economy - while Scotland and Wales have tightened the screws by pushing ahead and saying what will happen next. For all the argument and debate, we still donapost have a date when lockdown will be relaxed. And we know it wonapost actually end - it will just be eased bit by bit. But we have ious clues and leaked details which point to how that might happen. Weaposll relax lockdown once the infection rate is low enough, and then use a test, trace, track strategy with an NHS app to keep it low. Hereaposs everything we know about how lockdown will be relaxed, but why we must also get used to a aposnew normalapos that looks dferent to the UK we knew before.How long is the UKaposs coronavirus lockdown  The lockdown expires on May  - six weeks after it began. But thataposs just the legal date it has to be reviewed by. Emergency lockdown powers in the Health Protection Regulations  must be formally reviewed every three weeks. In reality the government will renew the lockdown for longer, at least partly. The question is how much of it will be extended, and for how long.  When will the UK lockdown end - and how  The UK lockdown will start to be relaxed once five tests are met:The NHS is able to cope A sustained fall in deaths New infections dropping enough Adequate testing and PPE No risk of a second peakBut once it is eased it wonapost all happen in one go. Instead the lockdown is set to be relaxed in phases while some social distancing measures stay in place. So while the strictest restrictions should start to ease this summer, some measures look set to be in place until next year. Stand-in PM Dominic Raab adds we might see restrictions tighten in some ways and loosen in others. How will the government decide itaposs time to relax the lockdown  The UK government will have to fulfil all five testson ending the lockdown. Downing Street adds the key test will be how far and fast the infection rate drops. aposRapos - the number of people each carrier infects - is already below , which stops Covid- spreading exponentially. But Health Secretary Matt Hancock has warned it wouldn’t take much to lose that grip. Any change to the restrictions must not risk the aposRapos number going above .So how will we know when thataposs happened  The key piece of evidence will be a study by the Office for National Statistics on the infection rate - expected to be published in early May. That could be crucial in deciding what the government does next. Despite pleas from Tory MPs, Downing Street insists the decision will be based on science before the economy. Boris Johnsonaposs spokesman said: We will have to take decisions based on the best available scientic and health advice. it’s not going to be a case of choosing between the economy and public health.”Will lockdown be relaxed before May   Government sources said there would likely be more details spelt out before May . But officials later insisted that wouldnapost actually mean a clear exit plan - it more means an update on the infection rate. The Prime Ministeraposs official spokesman told a Westminster briefing: Weaposve set out that we will review social distancing measures by May . The Government is focused upon that date. Once lockdown is relaxed, what happens then  If the virus spikes again, lockdown could have tomultiple times with little notice. So the plan is to stop that happening with a three pronged strategy - test, trace and track. The government is hiring , human contact tracers and will encourage people to download an NHS app. Put together, the system should noty people when theyaposve been in contact with a Covid- carrier - so they can immediately isolate and stop it spreading further. But there are concerns about how well it will work. The NHS says the app will be launched in the coming weeks. It will use Bluetooth to log each time your phone moves near another personaposs phone with the app. If one of those people is later diagnosed with Covid-, you would get an alert warning you to get tested and self-isolated.  What will reopen first and what will stay shut  The UK government has refused to say officially - and thereaposs not yet a firm decision. But plenty of speculation has been leaked. And we can also pick up clues from Scotland and Wales, which have been more open about their plans. Schools and some non-essential shops seem very likely to reopen first, with modied layouts to ensure people can stay two metres apart. But hairdressers and nail bars could remain shut for six months, sources told The Sun. Working from home could become the new normal until thereaposs a vaccine, government advisors have said. And UK and Scottish ministers have warned pubs and mass gatherings could be among the last to reopen. PM Boris Johnsonaposs spokesman said: There will be judgments based on scientic and health advice of what is possible without increasing the risk of a second peak.” That could have to mean extending the aposfurloughapos scheme for staff to get up to % of their pay while out of work. The scheme currently expires in June but No will continue to keep it under review. It’s our intention to stand by both workers and businesses, a spokesman said.  Will some people be let out earlier than others  Itaposs possible. The government has looked at an idea of loosening restrictions on younger, healthier people first in order to get the economy moving again. And people could meet small bubbles of wider friends and family under one idea being looked at in Scotland. If that idea does happen, youaposd have to pick the same small aposbubbleapos of people to meet day-to-day, week-to-week - and carry on staying away from everyone . None of you would be able to go outside your aposbubbleapos.  Will people have to wear face masks  Itaposs not clear yet. Ministers are considering how to act on advice from the governmentaposs scientic advisors SAGE. The group decided there is weak evidence of a small effect in which a face mask can prevent someone whoaposs already infected, infecting those around them. Scotland has advised its residents to wear face coverings, either a mask or improvised facial shield such as a scarf, in limited circumstances in public when they have to be in close quarters with others. This is not mandatory. Why have Scotland and Wales got dferent plans - and what does it mean  Deep splits have opened up in the strategy across the UK. Wales and Scotland are both pushing ahead with telling the public what post-lockdown might look like, but the UK government refuses to say. So far, the actual plans remain pretty similar in each country - in fact, Matt Hancock has said Scotlandaposs plan is pretty similar to what heaposs been looking at. Itaposs just the communication with the public that has been split. But that risks changing as Wales and Scotlandaposs chiefs - who sit on crucial COBRA meetings about the lockdown - pile pressure on Boris Johnson and have powers over places like schools and care homes. The split forced the Health Secretary to plead for unity, saying: So far we have moved as one United Kingdom and I think that has been a very good thing. My preference is that we work together as one country. A Downing Street spokesman warned the nations: I’m sure they like us will be guided by the science - and won’t want to do anything that could risk a second peak”. Whataposs happening in Scotland  Scotlandaposs First Minister set out a -page blueprint for easing the lockdown. Nicola Sturgeon said businesses might be able to reopenthey can keep customers and staff  metres apart. The same would have to be in place in schools with modications needed in some classrooms. But pubs and mass gatherings would likely have to remain closed for longer. Despite spelling out an exit strategy, Ms Sturgeon warned normal as we knew it is not on the cards in the near future. Nicola Sturgeon said lting the lockdown is not a flick of the switch moment but more of a gradual change to the current conditions. No insisted Scotlandaposs plan was actually pretty similar to its own in terms of what needs to happen before lockdown ends.  Whataposs happening in Wales  Walesapos First Minister Mark Drakeford said lockdown could be left in three phases, like a traffic light in reverse. The red phase would see only the most careful and controlled lting of restrictions, amber would see more restrictions lted andthe virus does not re-emerge, Wales could move to the green zone. But he believed that UK ministers were nervous about entering into a similar conversation with the public for fear it would undermine the message to stay at home. The Welsh Government will also need seven questions to be answered before easing the lockdown. They are:Would easing a restriction have a negative effect on containing the virus  Does a particular measure pose a low risk of further infection  How can it be monitored and enforced  Can it be reversed quicklyit creates unintended consequences  Does it have a positive economic benefit  Does it have a positive impact on people’s wellbeing  Does it have a positive impact on equality

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAnxiety symptoms can often be very similar to those of coronavirus, doctors warn. With the death toll of those with Covid- on the sharp rise again in the UK today, doctors say it is unsurprisingwe feel particularly anxious at the moment.But some symptoms of anxiety are physical ones, unlike psychological symptoms which largely affect our mind. Tightness in the chest and shortness of breath are telltale signs of anxiety - but can also be symptoms of coronavirus. Dr Sarah Jarvis, clinical director of Patientaccess, said: Some of the symptoms of anxiety and panic attacks – feeling short of breath, palpitations, dizziness etc – are sometimes also seen in coronavirus. The doctor, though, suggested ways to tell that itaposs definitely anxiety and not coronavirus. . Shortness of breath Dr Jarvis said people take a few minutes to check in with themselves and try to steady their breathing. The symptoms of panic attacks tend to settleyou concentrate on your breathing and take very slow breaths, she added. Try tummy breathing - put one hand on your chest and the other on your tummy. You should aim to breathe quietly by moving your tummy with your chest moving very little. If you were able to calm yourself down and find a steady breathing pattern within those few minutes, you may not be dealing with coronavirus. But the World Health Organisationsaysyou have coronavirus your chest may begin to feel tight or you begin to feel as though you cannot breathe deeply enough to get a good breath. Shortness of breath associated with the Covid- infection is progressive in nature and can become le-threatening over a period of hours to days without medical care. - - - - - - - - ,- - ,+ - ,  . Problems with digestion Stomach pains, constipation and diarrhoea are signs of anxiety, doctors say. This is largely because the communication system between your brain and the enteric nervous system, which governs your digestion, is affected by stress. Of course, eating foods that don’t agree with you or not exercising can affect your digestion too. However, researchers recently studied data from  patients with Covid- in China’s Hubei province and discovered that . per cent of these patients arrived at the hospital with digestive symptoms such as diarrhoea, vomiting or abdominal pain. These symptoms, though, were usually accompanied by more typical signs such as a dry cough and high temperature. Therefore,you are only experiencing digestive issues it is unlikely to be coronavirus.  . Increased heart rate An increased heart rate is a classic sign of anxiety, according to the National Institute of Mental Health . Adrenal glands churn out hormones when you are faced when something stressful. So, receptors in your heart react by speeding up your heartbeat as a result. This lets you to pump more blood to your big muscles so you could theoretically flee or combat a threat. However, a racing heart rate can also signal coronavirus, doctors suggest. Dr As Munaf, an NHS consultant, said an elevated heart and breathing rates could indicate “you’ve potentially got signs of an infection, which in this climate could be Covid-”. If itaposs an anxiety attack, your heart rate should settleyou concentrate on your breathing and take very slow breaths. However,itaposs coronavirus your heart rate is likely to remain fast - especially during any form of exercise or movement.  . Muscle pain Your muscles tense up as part of your stress responseyou are suffering from anxiety. Many people with anxiety report feeling tight in their neck, back, or shoulders. But, likewise, some coronavirus patients report muscle soreness across their body. According to WHO, about  per cent of all Covid- patients experienced body aches or joint pain. These aches are triggered by chemicals called cytokines - which the body releases while responding to the infection. Muscle pains in coronavirus patients, though, are usually accompanied by other more well-known symptoms. If you are worried about your symptoms, you can ring  for the NHSapos dedicated service. To protect others, do not go to places like a GP surgery, pharmacy or hospital.

Jamie Hunter and partner Beccy Flint found out they were expecting their first child together last year with a due date of the end of May . But in October last year teacher Jamie started to suffer a crippling pain in his side. After lots of tests and scans he was finally diagnosed with kidney cancer in March, reports Birmingham Live. Last month the -year-old was told the cancer had spread to his liver and there was no cure.  The brave couple, from Sutton Coldfield, have made the decision to deliver their baby on May  in the hope Jamie can have the chance to meet and cuddle his newborn. Best friend Phil Taylor said: Jamie will never be able to celebrate his baby’s first birthday, teach them to ride a bike and learn to swim or be there for their first day at school. These are the things we take for granted.  Asle isn’t cruel enough, Beccy may have to face childbirth without Jamie, as his health is deteriorating every day. Phil, who met Jamie  years ago, and friend Chad Duggan have launched a crowdfunding page in a bid to raise £, to support Jamieaposs care, his family and Baby Hunter. There has been a huge response to the appeal and it has been retweeted by Aston Villa captain Jack Grealish. They were over the moon about having a baby, it was everything heaposs wanted, said Phil, who is a plumber. Heaposs always put himself out for everyone  before himself. He has managed two under-sevens teams right through to under-s and onto adult teams. Jamie is also a huge Manchester United fan with a massive heart, who has dedicated his le to football and teaching. He added: Heaposs godfather to my daughter and my best friend. I know the money we raise isnapost going to keep him here. If it could, Iaposd give it all back. But I thought we should do whatever we can to support Beccy and the baby. Jamie, who works as a PE teacher at John Wilmott School in Sutton Coldfield, joined Sutton United as a teenager and ed as a manager and coach after deciding to stop playing in .  Phil said: He has taken teams from six and seven years of age all the way through to adult football. Jamie loved this so much he did it twice! He added: As a PE teacher, he has touched so many lives and has been an outstanding role model, developing young people through all walks of le. The kids love him at school, heaposs always helping kids. Alongside his amazing coaching efforts he also played for the clubaposs first team. The friends hope to raise £, for Jamie and his family and have pledged a donation would be made to John Taylor Hospice,which has been supporting the couple, who met through football.

story: NewsCoronavirus: Why you need to brush your teeth just before leaving the houseMartin Addy, emeritus professor of dentistry at the University of Bristol, said he was surprised his profession had not promoted brushing as a preventative measure against coronavirusShareCommentsByMatthew Dresch:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsBrushing your teeth can reduce the viral load in your saliva and could help prevent coronavirus, a dental professor claims " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA dental professor has urged people to brush their teeth before leaving the house in a bid to prevent the spread of coronavirus. Martin Addy, emeritus professor of dentistry at the University of Bristol, said toothpaste can reduce the chances of catching or spreading the disease through the mouth. However, he warned that the antimicrobial effect of toothpaste only lasts from three to five hours. He therefore suggested Brits brush their teeth before going outside to ensure the effect is active should they come into contact with other people. In a letter in yesterdayaposs Times, Mr Addy, wrote: Scientists, in support of mouth and nasal coverings, have emphasised the role of saliva droplets in the spread of Covid-. Follow our live blog for the latest updates about coronavirus It is perhaps surprising, therefore, that toothbrushing with toothpaste has not been emphasised as an effective procedure.Toothpaste contains the same detergents as those found in handwash gels recommended against coronavirus.Indeed, the antimicrobial action of toothpaste in the mouth persists for three to five hours and, thereby, would reduce the viral load in saliva or infection by viruses entering the mouth. Mr Addy said people wanting to maximise the preventative effects could brush their teeth just before leaving the house. He added: As a large proportion of our population is in lockdown, one of the brushings could be immediately before leaving home for exercise, shopping etc. For those workers in the NHS, brushing should be before putting on protective equipment.

Seven-year-old Leo and Havana, five, were the most important things he and we Maureen had in the world. Eric had been fit and healthy before falling ill with bowel cancer aged just . Three months later he tragically passed away. But in his final days, he shared a last wish he hoped would bring happiness to his grieving family when he was gone - and now his widow has made that a reality. Speaking bravely to The Mirror today on the first anniversary of Eric’s death, Maureen recalled: “When we knew that his diagnosis was terminal we talked about the children and things that we could do to make things a little better for them and help them with their grieving...which included getting a pet.”  Following her husband’s passing, Maureen, , went online and found two perfect cats called Betty and Ethel who were looking for a loving home. Maureen, who recently moved from Chester to live in London, recalled: “The owners were happy for me to come to collect the cats with the children on what would have been my husband’s th birthday.  “So I picked them up from school and told them that papa had a special present for them, the biggest present theyaposve ever had because he loves them so much and wants them to be happy. I also wanted to make his birthday a happy occasion for the children.  “When I introduced them to the cats they were very surprised, shocked. They couldn’t believe it. “Now Betty and Ethel are part of our family and of our new chapter. The children adore them. They love it when the cats come to sleep in their beds. They love stroking them, giving them treats and playing with them. Also it’s nice to have a full house again.  “My husband worked from home so it felt very empty when he passed away. It was also nice in the evenings to chill with the cats when the kids go to bed.”  Maureen has bravely shared her story as part of IAMSapos latest campaign celebrating the magic of pets and the iniduality of each animal.   IAMS champion the joy of your pet’s healthy vitality. The joy of healthy vitality is not simply visible health or your cat or dog’s happiness it is a powerful combination of the two together. And that’s why IAMS want to help the nation’s pets live healthy, active and happy lives through the expert nutrition they truly enjoy. No compromise. An incredible % of cat owners recommend IAMS for Vitality*, which provides a complete and balanced diet for your pet. IAMS promises high quality nutrition with a great taste for healthy vitality.  Maureen said Betty and Ethel have had an incredible impact on her family - and agreed each and every pet has its own unique personality. She added: “their personalities are very dferent. Ethel is more socialable. She loves to be in the mix and doesnapost mindthe kids pick her up. She tends to follow us around more and is always at the door when we come home. Betty is quieter and more timid. She also loves to chill out with us but is more adventurous when she goes out.  “They both love dry and wet food - gravy-based specically. title: mischievous toddler shaves huge patch
story: NewsMischievous toddler shaves huge patch off her hair using dog clippersSariah Coombs, from Hawarden, north Wales, wandering around her home with clumps of long, blonde locks falling from her head after her mischiefShareCommentsByBradley JollyDigital journalistTfany Wallis:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsSariah Coombs, two, ran away with the familys dog clippers" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A cheeky toddler shaved off a huge patch of her hair with dog clippers when her mum thought she was just watching TV.Little Sariah Coombs, two, snuck off with the clippers when mum Sian, , had her back turned and contrived to hack her locks. And minutes later, Sian found her daughter wandering around their home in Hawarden, north Wales, with clumps of long, blonde locks falling from her head. My daughter is absolutely doggy obsessed and she loves to help me but the dogs didn’t enjoy her brushing them so I gave her a bowl of treats to feed to the dogs to distract them while I brushed, Mrs Coombs said today. She was doing a great job and by feeding the treats to the puppies, she kept them distracted and it kept her entertained too - so all was going well. I just assumed she’d gone to join her other siblings watching TV or something. But she ed moments later holding the dog clippers in her hand, and as soon as I spotted her holding them, I leapt to get them off her but then noticed what she had done. Mrs Coombs , who is also mum to Thomas , Amara , Henry seven, and five-year-old Percy, panicked as she realised Sariah managed to shave a whole patch down the middle of her head.  She said: The hair was still sort of stuck to her head, but as I began touching it, clumps came away in my hand and I could see what had happened. Sariah’s first reaction was to say mummy did it as Sian was left standing with clumps of her daughter’s hair in her hands. Despite her initial reaction being gobsmacked, Sian said in hindsight she is relieved her toddler didnapost take the clippers to one of the dogs as they have a litter of seven-week-old puppies in the house.  She said: My first instinct was of course one of horror, but I saw the big smile on her face change into an anxious expression when she saw my face so I quickly realised I needed to hide my own feelings to protect her. She’s still breastfed so immediately upon realising there was a problem she asked for ‘bobos’ so I just fed her to calm her down, and give me time to gather my thoughts a little. I didn’t show her the result of her hair until a little while later but she just laughed when she saw herself in the mirror which I was relieved about.  Describing her little one as absolutely full of le, Sian said her cheeky little girl is into everything at the moment. She said: She copies me with every task I do and she’s very bright. I don’t think there’s much in my house that she doesn’t know where it belongs or how it works. She notices everything and just loves to join in and help out. Just days earlier, Mrs Coombs said she had spotted Sariah checking all of the puppies with a stethoscope - so she is glad she didn’t decide to give them all a haircut. The mother said it was also heartwarming to see how none of the other children seemed to mind about their youngest sibling’s new hair-do.  Mrs Coombs added: My children didn’t say much to be honest. They don’t really care what her hair is like, they just love her for who she is regardless of anything . They all immediately went out onto the trampoline and played together like nothing had happened. My eldest was probably the most shocked, my teenage daughter just thought it was funny and the younger boys have barely mentioned it. However, Mrs Coombs admitted that her husband, Paul, did questionshe was joking when she messaged him to tell him the news. She said: He feels the same as me. We just love her to bits and want her to be happy, nothing  matters. These things happen in le sometimes.  Sian said she considered shaving off the rest of Sariah’s hair, but has decided to leave it after reaching out for some advice. She added: I messaged my hairdresser and a few hairdresser friends who all told me to leave it be. I also asked Sariah and she got upset at the thought of having the rest shaved. My only concern now is to protect her feelings. She doesn’t want it cutting so I won’t. I just want her to feel happy and not worry about it so we’re not making an issue of it.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA paramedic who tested positive for coronavirus has warned it can trigger unusual symptoms after she got it without suffering a cough and high temperature. Kirstine Adkin said she couldnapost taste raw garlic, ground coffee or cinnamon. The -year-old NHS medic then lost all sense of smell and taste as she fell sick  with the killer virus. At first she started with a headache and back ache but put it down to work stress. But her condition deteriorated and she was left struggling to breathe. The South Western Ambulance Service medic is now warning people to be on the lookout for less obviousapos symptoms and to heed Government advice to stay indoors.  She said: Iaposm a - year-old girl working on the front line as a NHS paramedic. I tested positive for Covid- and wanted to share my experience to warn others who display less aposobviousapos symptoms like I did at first. She added: I am now well and Iaposm feeling very grateful that I am able to continue to work when so many people are facing real hardship during this crisis - Iaposm one of the lucky ones right now. Day One Kirstine, of Poole, Dorset, has decided to share a diary covering her week-long fight against the deadly bug which has so far claimed more than , lives in the UK. It began with headaches. She wrote: Day  - I developed severe headaches above both eyes, which got worse and worse. The worst headaches Iaposve ever had. Day Two Kirstine began experiencing back aches. Day  - I woke up with a headache, but put it down to stress headaches. Given the current situation at work, I didnapost think a headache was very signicant. About mid day I started getting a really achy back. Again, working as a paramedic involves lting people down the stairs. Itaposs not uncommon for me to get an achy back. However that night the pain in my back was so bad I realised that this probably wasnapost my normal aches.Day Three The aches got worse and spread around her body, as she lost her sense of smell. Day  - I woke with full body aches still mostly in my back and my head I called in sick, still unsure whether I was doing the right thing as I didnapost have a cough, no temperature. Was it just a bad back and headaches due to the stress weaposre all under  Later that day everything got worse, I didnapost leave bed, and by the evening I had some pains in my chest and felt a little breathless when moving around. I decided to disinfect my surfaces in my bedroom, and thataposs when I realised I couldnapost smell a thing. I proceeded to smell everything around the house, but absolutely nothing! Day Four A mild cough began and Kirstineaposs sense of taste vanished. Day  - The aches and pains started to improve. Only today I developed a slight dry cough. The coughing was constant for an hour or two in the morning but then was so spread out Iaposd maybe only have an episode of coughing once every  hours. I realised today that I also couldnapost taste although I probably couldnapost yesterday but I didnapost eat anything to notice.

title: pregnant woman tears shop worker
story: NewsPregnant woman in tears as shop worker says she must queue like everyone Amanda Grant, from Wavertree, Liverpool, and who is due to give birth in just six weeks, visited a branch of The Range in the city on SundayShareCommentsByCharlotte HadfieldBradley JollyDigital journalist:,  APR NewsAmanda Grant, , has been struggling to stand in supermarket queues for long periods of time " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters.
