title: 750 families receive food parcels from district hub
story: NEW community co-ordination hubs set up to deliver essential supplies to vulnerable residents across the district have delivered over  food parcels.Downpatrickrsquos Down Leisure Centre is one of three hubs set up by Newry, Mourne and Down Council to distribute parcels to those who have been advised to stay at home.The Market Street facility has been transformed into a new distribution centre to help meet the needs of people who have been confined to their homes as part of the governmentrsquos lockdown measures.And with restrictions on movement set to remain in place for at least three more weeks, the new community hubs will have an increasingly important role to play.Between April  and ,  food parcels received from the Department for Communities were distributed from new community co-ordination hub distribution centres in Downpatrick, Newry and Kilkeel. In addition, another  food parcels were delivered by last Friday.Local council officials have been working in partnership with their colleagues across local government, health trusts and the Department for Communities to set up the hubs.Down Leisure Centre has been transformed into a processing centre to organise deliveries, with other sites currently being identied should they be required, with staff working in split shts, while observing social distancing and other safety protocols.The new service covers the councilrsquos seven even district electoral areas with deliveries focusing on food supplies with the packages including items such as tinned and dried food, cereals and some essential toiletries.Requests for help from the council and its community and voluntary partners are arriving via Access NI which is processing calls from across Northern Ireland on a freephone helpline.Council chairman Charlie Casey says he is pleased to see just how many of the districtrsquos most vulnerable residents have been able to receive food parcel deliveries recently.ldquoOur sincere thanks go to all our partners who worked with us over the Easter break to achieve this and all the volunteers who have already kindly offered their help, he continued.ldquoIt is important that we provide a leline to those following medical advice to shield to protect their health, or who are self-isolating, and have no other means of assistance.The council chairman said that during the local authorityrsquos COVID- response, it will continue to work hard to deliver essential supplies to those who need them and ensure no-one feels alone or isolated at this dficult time.A COVID- community helpline is operational, with those in vulnerable groups seeking support asked to make contact between am and pm, seven days a week, with the helpline managed by Advice NI who are processing calls from across Northern Ireland.The Freephone number is   , while the email is covid@adviceni.net. Contact can also be made by texting ACTION to .All calls that are relevant to the councilrsquos community co-ordination hub will be passed on to the local authority for action, including referrals from the South Eastern and Southern health trusts.The Downpatrick-based County Down Rural Community Network, the Confederation of Community Groups in Newry and Community Advice Newry Mourne and Down are acting as lead organisations for the community groups involved in this response.Members of the public are reminded that the Down Leisure Centre remains closed and that anyone who requests a food parcel will have it delivered to them directly.The County Down Rural Community Network in Downpatrick is acting as one of the lead organisations for the community groups involved in the response to the new food parcel distribution service.Any other volunteers who wish to assist in the delivery of food and supplies or ensure residents on their own at this time receive phone calls to help ease their isolation, are encouraged to register with Volunteer Now via their website.Further information about volunteering is available at www.volunteernow while organisations can identy COVID- volunteering requirements at www.volunteernow organidations.prettyPhoto

title: Castlewellan dressmaker makes scrubs for frontline workers in lockdown
story: FROM wedding dresses to scrubs ndash thatrsquos the new order of work for Castlewellan bridal dressmaker Shirley Moorhead.Sewing a range of scrubs for nurses and nursing home workers has replaced Shirleyrsquos normal orders of stunning gowns, veils, bridesmaidsrsquo dresses and outfits for the mother of the bride and groom since the coronavirus lockdown.The  year-old was facing a full order book for spring and summer weddings until the lockdown resulted in many weddings being pushed back to the autumn and beyond.The woman behind Fairytale Designs, the mother of five was determined not to let her inactivity and seamstress skills go to waste during the lockdown over the last four weeks.She is now sewing scrubs for over  hours each day in her garden workshop, after  years of experience as a dressmaker.ldquoIrsquom sure that in any home where there is a sewing machine, local people are also doing their bit and working to sew to support the local effort with PPE, said Mrs Moorhead.ldquoAt the moment, while Irsquom being very productive, I canrsquot earn a living with what I do, like so many others. Therersquos plenty like me and we are all in the same boat.ldquoIt started when I received requests from nurses who I made their wedding or bridesmaid dresses in the past for. I ended up making scrubs for some entire hospital wards, male and female and in a iety of sizes.ldquoThat widened out to sewing for staff at local nursing homes. I just want to do something to help, particularly for nursing homes as my daughter, Abigail, works in one in Castlewellan.There is plenty of work to be done to complete her bridal orders, but Mrs Moorhead feels that her priority is for scrubs.ldquoMy weddings have been pushed back until October or November or even next year. There are things that would hamper me. I canrsquot see brides to fit them and I wouldnrsquot want to go too far ahead with orders in case some people gain weight or lose weight, she said.ldquoAlso,the wedding changes seasons, that can change the outfit ordered in style and colour. For instance, a mother of the bride might want a jacket as well or might want to lose or shorten sleeves so I feel I canrsquot go to far ahead with my orders. Brides have needed me to reassure them that everything will be alright for their big day, whenever it happens, and I can absolutely promise that.ldquoAbigail is getting married in November and her sister, Johanna, is getting married next May, so they will be the most special wedding dresses I will make in my letime. I feel that I have to keep going with the scrubs as itrsquos so important. However, I will make sure that I will provide all outfits that have been ordered from me. It has become a family affair as Mrs Moorheadrsquos husband, Joe, who also is unable to work as an engineer in the lockdown, helps with the pressing of the garments while Johanna helps with the sewing.Mrs Moorhead has been creating the scrubs from donated material, much of it brand new, and is very grateful for the donations..prettyPhoto

title: Crossgar man takes Chance with move to Hong Kong 26 years later opens superstore
story: AT the age of  and without a word of Cantonese, Richard Bowsie left his family and friends behind in his home village of Crossgar for a le of adventure in Hong Kong.Twenty-six years later and now a married father of two, Richard has found love, happiness as well as a successful career as the owner of two second-hand furniture stores in the huge cosmopolitan city with over seven million inhabitants.He and his locally-born we, Mavis, run nd Chance Furniture that provides shoppers in the city and online across the world a virtual Aladdinrsquos Cave with thousands of unique and affordable items - ranging from lacquered tables to pool tables, Chinese vases to Balinese drums.While other young ambitious men were told to lsquogo westrsquo, Richard went east, finding Hong Kong to be every bit as much the land of opportunity as the United States.The father of eight year-old daughter Kailey and son George, whorsquos coming five, literally changed his le in three days when he made the decision to fly to Hong Kong.From working as a leguard at the Tropicana centre in Newcastle and at the former Down Leisure Centre, the former student of the High School, Ballynahinch, had been close to completing his BTec qualication in Leisure Management at the former Newcastle College of Further Education.He ped out of his course a few months shy of graduation due to bullying. While his parents, Margaret and Ken, a well-known architect, were shocked at their middle sonrsquos decision, they were not surprised.He recalled: ldquoI had a friend who had travelled to Hong Kong three months previously. During a phone call he told me that the new international airport was under construction and work was easy to find. Three days later I arrived.ldquoI decided to go by myself as I had been trying to find an exciting job at home for a while but kept being told I was too young for the roles or lacked experience. My parents knew I was ambitious and how frustrated I was becoming with my career ambitions being knocked back all the time.Richard admitted he hadnrsquot a clue what to do once he arrived and took a bar managerrsquos job as an interim position as many of the airport workers drank there.His first job at the airport turned out to be with the Northern Ireland company, Lagan Construction Group, before going to another Belfast-based company, Rotary International, with which he worked for two years.ldquoI felt excited and nervous all at the same time when I first moved to Hong Kong, said Richard.ldquoThe first thing that struck me was the heat, after leaving cold and damp of home. Arriving in  degrees and high humidity was certainly a shock to the system, despite having been on family holidays to France most years with my family and once to America with a cross community group. The heat in Asia was a massive shock.Having grown up in a rented manse on the Rademon estate, Richard swapped a quiet rural existence for the hustle and bustle of the global port and major commerce centre. It was still under British rule and would remain so for another three years before it was handed back to China.Richard said: ldquoLanguage was the biggest shock but I made it my mission to learn the language and enrolled in YMCA lessons but also managed to pick it up from also working alongside locals.It wasnrsquot long before Richard felt confident enough to start out his own business, an electrical supply company which employed  staff.He said: ldquoI knew after the first few months that Hong Kong was going to work for me,you worked hard, nothing could hold you back, age was not an issue here. Opening a business here was very straight forward, just need a bank account and register an address.He met his we Mavis during his first month in the city and the two have been together ever since.They opened their first store in  in the after seeing a large amount of good furniture being thrown away each week and were determined to do something that would reduce the waste and help the environment. Within months, they had outgrown this store and relocated to their current , sq ft premises in Tuen Mun.The couple has recently opened a second, , sq ft premises in Chai Wan which is closer to the busy capital.Fluent in Cantonese for many years, Richard has seen Hong Kong go through many challenges, not in the least with the recent coronavirus pandemic.ldquoHong Kong has handled the virus very well, having been through SARS and bird flu before, said Richard. ldquoAs soon as we heard there was an issue over the border in China, Hong Kong went straight into prevention measures before even being advised to. Now everyone wears masks and observes hygiene measures.The preventative measures must have been successful as the city recorded zero deaths on Monday for the first time since the outbreak before Christmas.While the move to Hong Kong was the right one for Richard, he still misses home and his brothers and sisters, Simon, Gillian, Laura and William.He said: ldquoI miss the food, the greenery and, of course, my family who are all still in Northern Ireland. I miss being close to home as I have lost family members and grandparents.ldquoBut we come home as often as we can. Mavis and the kids love Crossgar, especially AJs Diner. They love the Rademon estate where we lived beside, walks down the Church Road to Kilmore and the open green fields. We have very few here in Hong Kong and any we do have are full of mosquitos.Home is always on Richardrsquos mind, as is his business.He adds: ldquoNext for our business is hopefully more expansion as I would like to start exporting furniture to other countries such as Northern Ireland. I have discussed this with some Co Down firms in the past, so watch this space..prettyPhoto

title: Downpatrick jockey Declan lands seven winners
story: DESPITE the fact that the - season has been curtailed, it is good to record that Downpatrick amateur jockey Declan Lavery rode an excellent tally of seven winners, one ahead of Banbridge farrier Mark OrsquoHare during the season.It is notable that while Lavery is based with Paddy Turley at Downpatrick, he rode his winners for Southern-based trainers like John Ryan and Luke Conner. OrsquoHare has the advantage as he is stable amateur to Navan trainer Noel Meade.Noel McParlan also got on the scoreboard and he was the top local point-to-point rider.Last week proved to be a sad one for local racing on Easter Sunday as Dr Fitz Gillespie, MBE, passed away suddenly at the age of . He was the GP in Tynan, Co Armagh, for  years.Dr Gillespie was one of the nicest men that I have ever met and was a long serving member of the Turf Club and IHRB. Although I donrsquot remember him riding, I know he did so for many years, and was also a trainer and owned horses right up to .His son, Pat, also rode as an amateur and professional, spending a good bit of his riding days with Jeremy Maxwell at Ballee. I can recall him winning on Raise An Argument at Downpatrick. Like his father, he also trained and one of his locally based owners was Joe McGrath, from Annacloy.Dr Gillespie was a regular steward at local meetings and also at many Southern racecourses. He was also a good supporter of the former Downpatrick Racecourse Supporters Club. He acted as a steward at the Armagh PTSP on April .He is predeceased by his first we, Dr Barbara, and also Lady Jane Alexander. He is survived by sons Pat and Rollo, daughter Gael, son-in-law, daughters-in-law and grandchildren.A memorial service will be held for Dr Gillespie at a later date as the funeral was private due to Covid-. He will be a huge loss to the sport of horse racing.It was also sad to learn this past week of the passing of the we of former Newtownardsamateur and well known horseman Albert Lowry and the widow of former amateur SammyPatton..prettyPhoto

title: Expressive view of life and scenery
story: NATURAL beauty abounds round every corner of the Lecale district, whether it is on land or water.The evocative scenery has inspired poets, writers, artists and photographers down the generations as they capture aspects of the familiar and everyday le from their distinctive viewpoints.This week the Recorder is featuring the work of four local artists ndash Conor Maguire, GwendaEarley, James G Miles and Micky Ferris.Belfast-born Conor now lives in the Downpatrick area. Find out more about him by logging on to www.connormaguire.Gwenda also lives and works in Downpatrick and some of her paintings show aspects of le in Killyleagh, particularly on the water.James lives at Tyrella and is an artist and sculptor, as well as being a singer and songwriter. Discover more about his work at www.jamesgmiles.net.Retired teacher Micky lives and works in Ballyhornan. His stylistic work reflects his childhood memories of holidaying in the area. You can find out more about him at Mickey Ferris Art on Facebook..prettyPhoto

title: Forest parks to reopen to public
story: TOLLYMORE and Castlewellan forest parks are to reopen to the public.The news mdash confirmed yesterday by the Department for Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs mdash has been welcomed by South Down MLA Colin McGrath.But car parks at both locations will remain closed, with Mr McGrath urging people not to park on roads and laneway which lead to both facilities.The Assemblyman says parking in the vicinity of both forest parks is an ldquoongoing source of annoyance and unhappiness for people in Castlewellan and Bryansford. He said those who leave their vehicles outside the parks do so to avoid paying entrance fees and walk in instead.ldquoBoth parks have been shut since the coronavirus outbreak and now the government department responsible for them has agreed that they can reopen, continued Mr McGrath.ldquoHowever, local people are concerned that the move to open the parks for pedestrians only will encourage people to travel from further away and park outside their entrance gates.Mr McGrath said agriculture minister Edwin Poots is encouraging police to patrol the areas outside the parks and to manage this accordingly.The MLA added: ldquoThis is something I would also endorse and urge people to remember that the parks are only open for pedestrians. People should not park vehicles in the streets around the entrances to both these facilities.Mr Poots said while pedestrian access will be available to all forest parks and country parks in Northern Ireland from today, car parks will not be open.He said: ldquoWe are not encouraging people to drive but for local communities having that facility on their doorstep is something they will be able to utilise for walking purposes only.Mr Poots said the parks are not for picnics, gatherings, or anything , but for walking purposes only, explaining that a bit of exercise is good for your mental and physical health..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C April 22%2C 1980
story: NEWCASTLE ndash Eleventh hour moves by two Government departments have blocked development of a large area of land needed for new public housing in Newcastle, it was learned this week.Officials of the Department of Environment and the Department of Agriculture have stopped Housing Executive negotiations because they are worried about drainage problems on the land and because they are examining a pound million scheme of their own for the area.But in a rare public outburst the Housing Executiversquos regional controller for the area, Mr Colin James, has attacked their late interference in his plans. Mr James said bluntly yesterday:ldquoThere are people who had an opportunity to say things at an early stage but did not. Now they have really pulled the carpet out from under our feet at an advanced stage. Irsquom bitterly disappointed at this kind of timing.The problem arose when the Housing Executive was in the final stages of preparing a scheme, which has been on the drawing board for several years, when it was told of the Government objections to a number of potential sites, including the Burren River catchment area and another, the most important, at the Dundrum Road end of the town.The Executive had finally got an agreement to purchase from the landowner of the Dundrum Road site and had made a final routine check with the Government departments before clinching a deal. It was only then that the objections were revealed by Stormont, which had been kept informed of all moves over the years.DOWNPATRICK ndash A Downpatrick woman has been named as one of the top ten lsquoWomen of the Yearrsquo by the readers of a daily newspaper.Mrs Terry Dunbar was selected by readers of the Belfastand is to be honoured at the Woman of the Year Luncheon in the City Hall, Belfast, next month.Mrs Dunbar works by day in the occupational therapy department of the Downshire Hospital, Downpatrick, and most of her spare time is spent in voluntary work for the mentally ill and mentally handicapped.She is secretary of the Newcastle Society for Mentally Handicapped Children and is leader of the Down Peter Pan Club for children under .One of the most successful activities of the club is riding. ldquoI take members to the Newcastle Riding Centre every other Saturday and the people there are very good.Mrs Dunbar also runs the Gateway Club at the Downshire Hospital where the members ages range from early s to elderly.KINAHALLA ndash The decision to scrap the Kinahalla Dam project in the Mournes has been welcomed this week as lsquoa decision of sanityrsquo.The comment was made by Dr Arthur Mitchell, chairman of Komrade , the main opposition group to the scheme.Dr Mitchell said: ldquoBasically Komrade is delighted with the decision of the Water Appeals Commission. They have agreed with us that the water which they required was not there and this scheme would have caused serious ecological damage.Confirmation that the objectors had won the fight over the Kinahalla scheme came on Friday, when the Environment Minister, Mr Philip Goodhart, said his department had accepted the findings of the Commission which came out against the pound. million project.News that the Commission had recommended the scheme should be ped was leaked last month. However, there was considerable doubt over whether the Department of Environment would agree to stand by the Commissionrsquos finding.Now that the Kinahalla scheme has been axed, the Government is to look to Lough Neagh to meet the growing water supply needs of Belfast and County Down.BALLYNAHINCH ndash Ballynahinch Chamber of Commerce has been asked to help get something done about the condition of the Fair Green in the town.A petition drawn up by local residents was handed in to the Chamber, asking them to bring the problem to the notice of the owners.The Green, at the junction of the Crossgar Road and Belfast Road, has been a bugbear with locals for a long time, and itrsquos hoped that pressure from the Chamber can bring about an agreement between the owners and Down Council, whereby the area may be given a much needed clean-up.The Chamber considered the petition at their full meeting last Tuesday evening, and are to seek help from the owners and the council, with a view to getting something done quickly.ARDGLASS ndash Ardglass Festival Committeersquos bar quiz came to a very successful conclusion on Wednesday night when last yearrsquos Festival quiz champions from the Dock Inn defeated the fancied challengers from Anchor Bar.Despite the lack of a really close contest, the large crowd were entertained and amused by some spirited and at times inspired answering.After coasting to a -point lead in the first round the Dock Innrsquos lsquoleague of gentlemenrsquo, John Howland, Billy Ross, Danny McGreevy and Peter Rodgers, were never really in trouble and held off the final round rally from the Anchor Inn to win comfortably.The trophies and cash prizes were presented by Mr Pat Irvine, Ardglass Festival chairman, who, in his remarks paid tribute to the organisers and to all who had played a part in making it such a tremendous success.KILLYLEAGH ndash Killyleagh Girlsrsquo Brigade celebrated their th anniversary at the weekend.The company presented their th annual display on Thursday and Friday evenings in front of capacity audiences in the Cooke Hall, and on Sunday, held a special anniversary service in st Killyleagh Presbyterian Church.The Rev J D Mark was chairman for the two nights of the display, with Mrs J McKnight, captain of Killinchy company and secretary of Strangford and Mourne District, the guest of honour on Thursday night. On Friday, the guest of honour was Mrs Harris, captain of nd Comber company and district commandant.Sundayrsquos service was well attended, with several other local companies represented. Also in the congregation were members of the Killyleagh Boys Brigade.The address was given by the Rev David Lapsley, of Fisherwick, who was minister at st Killyleagh  years ago. Also taking part in the service were the Rev J D Mark and the Rev J C Boggs.The bible readings were taken by Mrs Alice Gilmore, captain of the company, and Mrs Mary Berner, one of the founder officers.STRANGFORD ndash Prizewinners in a special poster competition with the theme of ldquoKeep Strangford Tidy have been announced this week.In the infant boys section, Colin Shields won first prize, with Colm Croke second. In the girls group of this section, Julie Craig took first prize with Anna-Marie Curran runner-up.Gemma McPolin took the honours in the lower juniors class, with Gillian Hynds second and Justin Sharvin third. In the upper juniors class first place went to Denise Craig, second was Orla Magee and third Oliver Curran.KILLINCHY ndash Killinchy Girlsrsquo Brigade held their th annual display on Friday and Saturday nights when the visiting officers were the Rev D Clarke and Mrs E Lynas.The girls gave a ied programme of fretwork, marching, and sketches before the presentation of prizes, by Mrs W Lowry on Friday and Mrs M Moore on Saturday.The chairman and visiting officers gave their remarks, and the GB secretary, Mary Thompsett, gave her annual report, touching on subjects including the district service, the past membersrsquo dinner, the youth service, the outing to the zoo, the barbecue, the GB camp, the PE training classes, the new times for the girls, the ious competitions, the enrolment service, the GB Week collection, which amounted to pound, the ure examination, the temperance examination, the badge work, the Duke of Edinburgh scheme, and the acknowledgement to parents for sending the girls along regularly..prettyPhoto

title: Increase in fly tipping in district as amenity centres stay closed
story: NEWRY, Mourne and Down Council has been urged to consider reopening the districtrsquos household recycling centres in a bid to deter illegal dumpers.The facilities in Downpatrick, Castlewellan and Ballynahinch mdash which closed at the start of the months as part of the COVID- response mdash each handle tens of thousands of tonnes of waste yearly.Rowallane councillor Billy Walker has appealed for the centres to reopen with his call made before news emerged last Friday that Mid and East Antrim Council had reopened oneis recycling centres in Ballymena, with others in Larne and Carrickfergus to open this week.Newry, Mourne and Down Council has invested heavily in its recycling centres, but their closure has led to a number of fly-tipping incidents across the district with the Downpatrick and Rowallane areas singled out as dumping hot spots.Council officials have confirmed that they have received increased reports about fly-tipping and appealed to people to store their waste until the centres reopen and revealed that while those who dump waste illegally can be fined pound, in some cases, more punitive penalties can be imposed by the courts.Cllr Walker says he is keen to see the districtrsquos recycling centres open again, provided the local authority can adhere to the current guidelines around social distancing.He is concerned about the number of recent fly-tipping incidents which he warned are not only unsightly, but pose a threat to livestock in rural areas in particular.ldquoI am aware that the closure of all the provincersquos recycling centres followed a directive issued by the Department for Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs. It is also my understanding that Newry, Mourne and Down Council and Northern Irelandrsquos other  councils are working closely alongside the government department at this time.Cllr Walker said he would like to see the recycling centres open again, suggesting that strict controls could be introduced to only allow two vehicles access them at any one time.ldquoI would also appeal to people at this time to keep their waste until the recycling centres are open again. I appreciate that many people who are not at work at the moment are making the most of the time they have to clean out their homes, sheds and garages and I commend them for being active.ldquoHowever, it simply isnrsquot on to load up you car with waste, drive to a secluded area and dump it. I just donrsquot understand the mentality of people who engage in this kind of behaviour.Cllr Walker also said the cost of clearing up illegal waste is borne by the districtrsquos ratepayers.ldquoWe have the ironic situation that those who dump their waste illegally end up paying for its removal viatheir rates. This beggars belief, he declared. ldquoThe stupidity of those who dump waste in secluded areas is beyond me.Cllr Walker added: ldquoThe time has come for common sense and people really need to catch a grip of themselves. One of the most worrying aspectsof illegal dumping is that waste which ends up in fields is sometimes eatenby livestock which often results in deadly consequences. To those who dump their waste illegal my appeal is stop now.The local council has confirmed that it is receiving increasing reports about fly-tipping across the district since the start of the COVID- crisis. But the organisation insists that it is currently able to manage the issue within existing resources.A council spokesman said that the organisation continues to work closely with the Environment Agency which also performs a key role in addressing incidents of larger illicit dumping.On the issue of reopening the districtrsquos household recycling centres, the spokesman explained that the decision is continually being reviewed in line with government social distancing measures.He continued: ldquoFly-tipping is illegal and the council will strictly enforce this where evidence can be gathered. Responding to fly-tipping incidents also erts important council resources away from providing other essential services.The spokesman confirmed that the council is unable to remove illicitly-dumped waste from privately-owned land, explaining that where this occurs, both it and the Environment Agency has the legal powers to request its removal.He said the council will enforce this where required.The spokesman added: ldquoThe council would urge the public to avoid producing any unnecessary waste, including undertaking DIY and house and garden clearances at this time due to the considerable pressure being placed on public services.ldquoAny additional waste that is produced should be stored for future disposal at the household recycling centres once they re-open. Further information on minimising and securing waste is available from the council website..prettyPhoto

title: Inspiring Newcastle student making PPE equipment
story: A STUDENT at Shimna Integrated College in Newcastle has been making good use of his time off school to support frontline health workers.Twelve year-old Mark Crawford has been busy helping his mum Keri-Ann Ross who works as part of a team making personal protection equipment for staff working in care homes and hospitals.Keri-Ann left an inspirational message on social media for Markrsquos Year  form teacher, Chris Smyth, and school principal, Kevin Lambe this week.ldquoGood news at this strange time, she said. ldquoMark has learnt a new skill and putting his time to good use.Keri-Ann, who works for South Eastern Regional College, added that Mark was happy to join in on the task helping the selfless teams of workers during the public health emergency.Mr Lambe commented: ldquoOn our school Facebook page we have been featuring the work of Shimna old scholar doctors, nurses, care assistants, ambulance staff and other front line workers.ldquoItrsquos great to hear from a current student working to support them with much-needed PPE..prettyPhoto

title: Into the Blues   Jake signs pro contract with Linfield
story: A TEENAGE local footballer says hersquos ldquoover the moon after signing professional terms with Linfield.Eighteen year-old Jake Corbett, from Dromara, has signed his first professional contract with the Blues after some stellar performances for Linfield Swts.The exciting young player has scored around  goals this season, despite playing in midfield.And he also helped the Swts lt the Steel  Sons Cup as they beat Newington - in the Christmas Day showdown.Jake, who joined the Windsor Park outfit three years ago, has been football mad since the age of ten.He played youth football for Dromore Amateurs, then broke his way into the clubrsquos first team and played in the Amateur League.After spells with Banbridge Town, Lisburn Distillery and Crusaders he joined Linfield at the age of .An attacking central midfielder, he made an immediate impact and firmly established himself in the Swts set-up.His prowess has also earned international honours. He first played for Northern Ireland as a  year-old and is in the Northern Ireland squad for this yearrsquos European U- Championships.Jake signed his professional contract last week. He said afterwards: ldquoI am absolutely over the moon to have signed a professional contract at Linfield.ldquoLinfield is a massive club with the best bunch of players which made my decision to sign much easier than expected. As everyone knows, itrsquos a dream come true to play for this big club.ldquoThis season for the Swts, Irsquove hit around the  goal mark from centre midfield, which everyone says is good, but Irsquod have preferred to have got even more.Jake got a taste of a professional footballerrsquos le when he was invited to join the Linfield first team squad on a trip to Marbella in Spain last year.ldquoIt was a real experience and a trip to remember. The whole trip made me feel hungrier and really knuckle down to get better and better, he remarked.ldquoTo be a professional footballer you need a completely dferent lestyle. There is much more training and fitness work. Everything has to be dedicated to football.Jake is maintaining his fitness regime, despite the coronavirus lockdown, and has developed his own programme with the help of Jonny Pierce, a personal fitness trainer from Lisburn.Jake says his ultimate ambition is a move to one of the big English clubs, but right now hersquos delighted with the progress of his career to date.ldquoYou have to keep your feet firmly on the ground. Irsquom definitely on the right track and I want to keep it that way, he added.Linfield manager David Healy said: ldquoJake has made a huge impression coming through the underage amateur ranks at the club and he fully deserves the reward of this professional contract.ldquoHe made a huge contribution to the success of the Swts in winning the Steel and Sons Cup at Christmas and I believe he has a bright and promising future ahead in the game..prettyPhoto

title: Loughinisland aiming for gold in club scheme
story: LOUGHINISLAND GAC is going for gold in the GAArsquos Club Maith accreditation scheme.The scheme allows clubs to be benchmarked against best practice standards across the full range of GAA club activity.The club, which now boasts  registered members, recently attained silver status through  points which includes good governance, community engagement, coaching and games, creating a safe environment and safeguarding members.This has been achieved through a strong volunteer base and has been achieved by a lot hard work by a large number of contributors.The silver status comes just months after Loughinisland GAC attained the bronze award.Paul McMullan, who has been the driving force behind the development team which helped secure the accolades, said ldquothis could not have been done without the entire volunteer base, everyone played their part and everyone contributed.He added: ldquoThese awards are physical evidence of the progress the club is making across the board.ldquoThey give us a strong springboard for success, providing accreditation with GAA and Sport NI which in turn will open up better opportunities for us going forward in terms of seeking grant aid to improve our facilities and also to support all the social initiatives the club is involved in from the very young to the older members of the community, and those who have a disability.ldquoAt the present time the club is seeking to put in place a package of measures to support all local people in the current crisis by the provision of physical support for the older and vulnerable who must self-isolate for an extended period and the provision of online classes to support all local people through the crisis.The Blue Wave, the clubrsquos five-year plan, comprised around % of the work for the bronze award and it was the springboard to help Loughinisland GAC achieve this recognition.Paul continued: ldquoThe plan and the work done around it has reinvigorated the membership and the volunteer base across all areas.ldquoThere is a lot of good work going on behind the scenes to make sure our governance is second to none.ldquoNew volunteers have come in and have made a great contribution, not just through fresh thinking and new perspectives but also because their contribution has impacted on the existing volunteer base, renewing it and giving it fresh impetus. There is a strong air of optimism about the club and the volunteer base.The club achievements in the past number of years include The Island Games, now in its fourth year the health and well-being centre, opened last year a mental health event the pound, weekly lotto draw a childrenrsquos summer camp which runs outside of Cul Camp senior citizensrsquo dinner new club mobile responsive website the club has signed up to Suicide Down to Zero, plus the GAArsquos volunteer development programme and sport uniting communities programme and the healthy clubs initiatives.Seamus Fay, Loughinisland GAC chairman, says he is delighted the club has achieved the silver and bronze Club Maith awards in such a short space of time.ldquoAttaining the bronze and then the silver award is a great testament to the hard work of Paul and his team and also to all the great groundwork that has been done in the club by many others over many years building strong foundations, he remarked.ldquoWe owe a great debt of thanks to all who have invested so much in this club and community.ldquoOur club and community plan, The Blue Wave, provides a strong focus in co-ordinating all our efforts so we are all working more effectively. We are delighted to obtain these awards but we will not rest on our laurels and intend now to apply for the gold award and to ultimately achieve platinum status which is the highest category available.ldquoWe want to keep improving, pushing up the standards both on and off the pitch, setting the bar higher for our players, coaches and administrators so we can achieve more. We need help to drive that on sowe will always welcome help from anyone in our community who can contribute in any way to building on our success.Paul added that the volunteers are continuing to help the vulnerable and older members in the area by assisting them with food and medical supplies which maintaining adequate social distancing.He said: ldquoAn incredible effort is being made by our volunteers and this is where the strength of our club lies ndash in its membership and volunteer base.ldquoThese awards are a recognition of all the hard work they have done over the last few years.ldquoOn behalf of the development team, which is overseeing the Club Maith process, I would like to thank them and congratulate them for all that they have done. These awards could not have been achieved without them..prettyPhoto

title: Loughinisland star releases new single
story: A LOUGHINISLAND teenager who stormed to the semi-finals of The Voice Kids last year has been enjoying rave reviews for his latest single.Fourteen year-old Conor Marcus says he is blown away by the interest shown by local radio stations since he released Hold Me Close Again just a few weeks ago on major streaming s.The soulful acoustic sound belies the fact that Conor is a Year  student at Shimna Integrated College in Newcastle. He was described by The Black Eyed Peas superstar Will.i.Am, who was a judge on the TV talent show, as giving ldquothe aura of having played a thousand Glastonburys.Conor has been playing guitar since he was nine years old and writing and performing songs since he was .He says his latest song is a little dferent to what he has written before.Conor added: ldquoI enjoy studying poetry in our English Literature classes and I believe this has helped me with my song writing ability.ldquoI love listening to other peoplersquos stories and usually draw inspiration from their perspective. This is the first song Irsquove written that pulls from my own experience.ldquoI wrote it a few months ago, after seeing artist Travis Gilbert. Itrsquos a song about some of my regrets, things I maybe wish I had done and didnrsquot feel brave enough to do at the time.Driven by the thousands of downloads his single has received online, Conor believes in the old saying that the lsquoapple never falls too far from the treersquo.He credits the influence of his father, Joe, on his music.ldquoMy dad and I would listen to a lot of old music. We are real music heads and both love bands from the past.ldquoQueenrsquos Bohemian Rhapsody is one such song. It has thousands of genres in that one song, said Conor.ldquoMy dad was in a band when he was my age. He was the bassist for a group called The Unbelievable Children and they won a competition not unlike The Voice.Following his success in The Voice Kids, where he was mentored by McFly frontman Danny Jones, Conor ed to busking on the streets of Belfast and Dublin, where he feels most at home.He says he is eager to follow in the footsteps of his hero Ed Sheeran and for the moment is content to hone his talent in the same way.Nevertheless, the star in the making is keen not to waste an opportunity like lockdown to write more songs for a forthcoming album.He finds the quiet rural setting he calls home with mum, dad and big sister Emer, the perfect place to conduct live streaming on Instagram to help promote his new single..prettyPhoto

title: Paddy Mo’s greatest Down side of all time
story: p.pp.pspan.s Paddy Doherty was a key member of the historic Down All-Ireland-winning team of . In a glittering playing career, the Ballykinlar man went on to win two more All-Ireland medals and established himself as one of the legends of the Gaelic football. Here, he selects his greatest Down team of all timeHIS name alone is enough to rekindle treasured memories of a time when Down football reigned supreme.Paddy lsquoMorsquo Doherty had the deadliest left foot in Ireland and he used it to maximum effect as Down swept all before them.Incredibly, itrsquos  years ago that Down took the sporting world by storm when they defeated Kerry to win the All-Ireland senior football title for the first time. It was also the first time that a team north of the border had won the Sam Maguire Cup.To reinforce their emergence as a new power in Gaelic football, Down retained their title the following year with Paddy as captain of the side which defeated Offaly and he was also a member of the Down team which won a third All-Ireland for the county in , Kerry again falling victim to the Red and Black machine in the final.As well as his three All-Ireland medals, Paddy won seven Ulster Championship, seven Railway Cup and three National League medals. He was the leading scorer in Ulster for eight seasons and in Ireland for three years.Now in his s, hersquos followed Downrsquos fluctuating fortunes ever since, relishing in theof the glory days in the early s, sharing in the disappointment of the barren times and casting a critical eye from the sidelines, though always with the optimistic outlook of the true fan.So what does he believe is the greatest Down team of all time Not surprisingly, given their accomplishments, hersquos largely selected his choice from his team-mates from the Sixties mdash though with typical modesty, he has not picked himself for the starting .ldquoYou have to remember that the Down team of s was the first to bring the Sam Maguire over the border, he says.ldquoThat was a really big achievement and we had beaten Kerry in the final. We had shown we were the best team in Ireland and we proved that again the following year in the final against Offaly after beating Kerry in the semi-final. We also beat Kerry in the  final, which meant that we had beaten them three times.ldquoKerry have always been the benchmark. If we had not beaten them, they would have won another three All-Irelands.Asked how his Down team would fare against present day sides ldquoItrsquos a dferent game now, what with the blanket defence and other things, but the Down teams of the s would have won in any era. Well, thatrsquos what I think, though Irsquom sure there are many people who would disagree. Eddie McKay Eddie won two All-Ireland medals with me in  and . He was a very good goalkeeper believe me, always safe, dependable and brave. He was an excellent shot stopper and made many excellent saves. I also played against him many times when Ballykinlar took on Dundrum. These were local parish derbies and everyone was trying to kill each other, but somehow Dundrum never managed to beat us. George Lavery George also won two All-Irelands in  and . He was the quiet man on the team, but there were few better man markers in the game and he would have been a star in any era. He had played a match of two for Antrim, but Maurice Hayes, who was secretary of the Down county board, persuaded him to sign for Down. He played as sweeper and was a good, tight marker. Leo Murphy Leo was a terric full back, tough and reliable. Not too many players could get past him and he could kick the ball a long distance. He also won two All-Irelands in  and . Pat Rice There was no one better than Pat Rice at catching a ball. His high fielding was magnicent and he was quick at clearing the ball. He gave away few chances and often kicked the ball out for Eddie McKay. He missed little and he wasnrsquot a dirty player at all. Dan McCartan One of only three Down players to win three All-Ireland senior medals along with Sean OrsquoNeill, Joe Lennon and myself, Dan is one of the all-time greats of Down football. He had outstanding ability, tackled hard and always looked for the quick clearance up to the front men. He could play anywhere as he showed when he moved to full back in the  final. Joe Lennon He was our captain in , though he did not play in the second after getting injured. He was a great captain and a terric leader. Joe placed a great emphasis on fitness and pioneered new coaching practices. He thought greatly about the game and was possibly ahead of his time. He was a very talented player. Tom OrsquoHare Tom played in the  team, but was good enough to get his place on any team. He was probably one of our best players that year. He was always steady and was great at delivering a ground ball. Jarlath Carey Jarlath won two All-Irelands in  and . He was a tireless worker, who was at home either in midfield or in attack. He was always forcing his way into the forward line and would wag his finger at me to go back into midfield to cover for him. I didnrsquot mind one bit, because he was good enough and I was fit enough to do what he asked. Colm McAlarney They called Colm lsquoThe Mighty Arklersquo after the famous racehorse because of his long strides up the field. Colm and Tom OrsquoHare were our two outstanding players in  and Colm was definitely one of the best midfielders in Ireland at that time, or any other time. Tony Hadden Tony won two All-Irelands in  and . He could fist the ball further than many players could kick it and he could also move into midfieldthings were going bad. He was tall and well built and could score a point as well as anyone. James McCartan A very strong player. Down would not have won anything without him because he took a lot of the abuse which would otherwise have been directed at me or Sean OrsquoNeill. He played a critical role in the  final against Offaly. We were two goals down in the first half and getting beaten. I crossed the ball to James who turned in mid air and put into the back of the net. Two more goals from Sean OrsquoNeill and Breen Morgan had us a goal up at half time, but it was his goal that turned things around. Sean OrsquoNeill You would have to say that Sean was the greatest Down footballer of them all. He was named in the GAA Team of the Century which says it all. We played well together, wherever I kicked the ball, Sean was there to get it. He had a wonderful sidestep and took a lot of abuse, but he never retaliated. He went on to become a successful manager and won the Sigerson Cup with Queenrsquos University. Mickey Linden Mickey was a flying machine and one of Downrsquos best ever forwards. He could blow defences away with his pace and score with either foot. He was also very versatile. You could play him anywhere and he would still be a threat. Perhaps his only failing was that he was too nice a player. He rarely made a foul. Won two All-Irelands in  and . Patsy OrsquoHagan Full forward and winner of two All-Irelands in  and . He could have played full forward, full back, or just about anywhere . He was that good. One of his best performances was Wembley Stadium during one of the Wembley Cup tournaments when he scored four goals against Galway. Breen Morgan They made them tough in Annaclone and for his size Breen was one of the hardest men on the field. He had broken his jaw before the  All-Ireland final, but went to the field without the protector which was made specially for him. He just threw it on to a chair. He was marked by Offalyrsquos Paddy McCormick, who was made of iron, but Breen was afraid of no one.Paddyrsquos substitutesDanny Kelly , Greg Blaney , Barry Breen , James Milligan , Ross Carr , Paddy OrsquoRourke , DJ Kane , Dan Gordon , Benny Coulter , Paddy Doherty ..prettyPhoto

title: Queen Karen Europe’s best
story: A KILLYLEAGH grandmother is a European powerlting champion at the age of .Karen Burns won the European title in France in March and set a new world record in the process.Powerlting involves three disciplines mdash squat, bench press and deadlt mdash and Karen capped a brilliant performance with a world record breaking lt of  kilos in the deadlt.Itrsquos a fantastic achievement for Karen, who only took up powerlting four years ago.The legal secretary, who has two daughters and four grandchildren, started gym classes at the age of , but within a few months made the switch to powerlting.Coached by Aaron Kelly, from Affinity Fit at the CG Fitness gym in Annacloy, she trained four times a week and was soon competing and winning medals at a national, international and world levels.She was the British champion two years running in  and . She was selected for Team GBR and last year finished second in the IPF world championships in Sweden.Karen says the journey to her European title and new world record began two years ago.ldquoMany people just see the training and programme side of things, but there is a lot more under the surface, she explained.ldquoDue to starting the sport later in le and competing against lters with -plus years under their belts I had to go to every extreme to give my progression every possible advantage.ldquoAll my food was tracked and measured. My diet is nutrient dense but I can still enjoy what I eat.ldquoWater intake was tracked, daily activity was tracked, recovery was tracked, which even included a curfew mdash my coach would literally check my fit bit data to seeI had gone to bed on time.ldquoI had to darken my room completely and remove the TV to improve sleep quality. Supplements, stretching, and home work-outs to improve mobility and prevent injury were all pieces of the puzzle.Owing to the coronavirus lockdown, Karen currently canrsquot get to the gym in Annacloy, but thatrsquos not stopping her training regime.She has set up a gym at her home in Killyleagh and is continuing her preparations for this yearrsquos world championships mdash they were due to take place in Sun City, South Africa, at the end of the month, but have been postponed. She hopes they will now take place some time later in the year.She said: ldquoI love this sport and my goals going forward are to continue to challenge myself and grow as a lter, but also to motivate and inspire others to enjoy heavy lting at any level, eventhey donrsquot want to compete.ldquoI want to help break the stigma that heavy lting makes you big and bulky and show others that at  Irsquom the fittest and strongest Irsquove been in my entire le, both physically and mentally..prettyPhoto

title: Saintfield man pens comedy dealing with life in lockdown during pandemic
story: A COMEDY play written by a multi award-winning film director from Saintfield has been published by a top London stage company.Gavin Irvinersquos debut play, Down The Plug Hole, has been described by Josef Weinberger Plays as ldquoabsolutely hilarious.Gavin, who is more used to scooping prestigious awards for his screen plays and directing talents, turned to writing his first play while he was confined at home as there coronavirus lockdown began.He says the play, with its contemporary back, depicts the vulnerability of society amid coronavirus.ldquoThe play is a metaphor for how it is for us all at the moment and poses the fundamental questions about le and where humanity may be headed, says Gavin, who is now based in London.Josef Weinberger Plays mdash more synonymous for their connection with renowned playwrights such as Arthur Miller, John Steinbeck and Eugene OrsquoNeill mdash put an open-ended call out to inspire dramatists everywhere to write a short play dealing with these days of quarantine and social distancing.Gavin says to have his first play published feels rather special. ldquoIf yoursquod told me that Irsquod be a playwright a month ago I wouldnrsquot have believed you.ldquoDown the Plughole is an absurd comedy about the catastrophic destruction of mankind, but set in a bathtub.ldquoIt deals with the uncertainty of our fate as a species as we contend with fatal diseases, an ageing society and the persistent threat of nuclear war from North Korea hanging over us ndash punctuated throughout by acts of God.Inspiration for the play came from a fate-filled moment when he was relaxing in a warm bath one evening as the lockdown began.He said: ldquoI live in Camden. I noticed within the first several days that I was able to breath more easily in the mornings and I was coughing much less. I am not a smoker.ldquoThe incessant pace of traffic in the street has slowed to a hush and my window sills inside my house are much cleaner. Before the lockdown, I could have drawn a line across the sills with my finger and it would have left a white mark in the soot which would gather.ldquoHaving the time that lockdown has inadvertently provided, I decided I would respond to a call-out to have-a-go playwrights to write something about their experience of self isolation.Gavin describes the scene as he pulled out the plug to let the water away. ldquoIt suddenly came to me as I watched the water drain away that it was an analogy for humanity, that we too are in great danger of being sucked down the plug hole to oblivion.So I got ready and immediately wrote the whole play sitting on the edge of my bed. It took me  minutes and I spent the next three weeks reworking it until I was happy.Central to the play is Jake, a man in his late s, who is in self-isolation and being cared for by his put-upon daughter, Martha.Gavin explains: ldquoWhile shersquos out getting groceries, he ponders upon the plight of the human race as it is metaphorically sucked down the plughole to oblivion.ldquoThroughout the play, Jake is visited by several characters mdash a City shark who represents the financial markets, a Navy er who see that humanity is in terrible trouble, the Prime Minister and God, who commands a less-than-enthusiastic Jake to build an ark and save mankind.Gavin says Jake becomes overwhelmed thinking that itrsquos too big of a job to build an ark. Hersquos not surehe has got the energy.ldquoThe play also includes two young mothers debating a brutal and radical way to build a new plug from the flesh and bone of every misfit in society, two floating dim-witted teenagers and a dancing bath plug bearing a last minute solution to the problem, said Gavin.ldquoAt the end of the play, Jakersquos lottery numbers come up and his winning ticket appears in the beak of a dove mdash the Christian symbol for peace.Down the Plughole, which reads as a tragicomedy, shines a spotlight on modern society and its impending doomlove and kindness fail to prevail.Gavin says he has taken inspiration from two comic plays, One Man, Two Guvnors by Richard Bean and Government Inspector by Nikolai Gogol, and the classic novel by William Golding, Lord of the Flies.Gavin added: ldquoJake realises that in the end money is worthless and that love and good health, which are in short supply in the play, are all that is important.Amelia Madan, head of amateur plays at Josef Weinberger Plays, said: ldquoDown the Plughole is a hilarious, ludicrous and bold play for these crazy unchartered times.ldquoWe are delighted Gavin chose to put some of the uncertainty about out fate as a species we all feel, into words, with a generous dash of delicious absurdism and a fabulous ending..prettyPhoto

title: Spa Wells LOL provide gift packs to health workers
story: LOCAL Orangemen have been looking out for frontline workers during the current public health emergency.Members of Spa Wells Orange Lodge distributed free gt packs which included Easter eggs and cosmetics for health workers based at two local nursing homes.Approximately  staff who care for elderly residents at Fishbourne House and Spa Nursing Home were thrilled to receive their pamper packs and thanked the lodge for thinking of them in the current situation.Lodge member John Aiken said they were delighted with the success of their community project and added they are currently working on another similar community-based initiative..prettyPhoto

title: serious conditions criteria esa claimants decided administrative officer
story: Despite a former government minister stating persons with serious conditions will no longer be repeatedly reassessed for Employment and Support Allowance , no legislation was introduced and Department for Communities staff have discretion on how this is administered.It has also emerged medical professionals with in-depth knowledge on the severity of claimantsrsquo health, who determine conditions permanent and serious, can be overruled by a Departmental administrative officer.With some members Fermanagh and Omagh District Council extremely perturbed by the current processes for those who are sick or disabled accessing benefits as well how and where appeals are conducted, the Local Democracy Service began an investigation into ious aspects of the system.One area examined was ESA and in particular, the Serious Conditions Criteria.In September  following an announcement by then Secretary of the Department for Work and PensionsDamien Green, people with the most severe, letime conditions would no longer to be repeatedly assessed for ESA and Universal Credit .Prior to that, even claimants with the most severe health conditions or disabilities were re-assessed on their availability for work.The Department for Communities announced it would ldquomaintain parity and follow this policy advising staff persons deemed to have lelong, and incurable conditions with minimally fluctuating care needs, would no longer undergo re-assessments. This would be known as Serious Condition Criteria.While widely welcomed, what was not made clear was Departmental staff have discretion around who meets criteria and can overrule a claimantrsquos medical evidence.A number of enquiries were submitted to the Department under a Freedom of Information request.The responses are concerning.The Department stated legislation does not refer to serious conditions but rather whether there is a relevant change of circumstances. The decision not to reassess those with severe, lelong disabilities or health conditions who are unlikely to ever move into work: ldquoTook effect from  September , but did not result in legislative change.The Department was asked about the right of appealing a decision rejecting a claimant for Serious Conditions Criteria, who responded: ldquoThere is no automatic right of appeal against a determination which is embodied in or necessary to a decision. , a claimant has a right of appeal against an outcome decision rather than a determination, which is merely a component of the outcome decision.This was complicated for non-legally trained or represented claimants, so questions were put around full compliance with the Disability Discrimination and Human Rights.The Department responded stating it: ldquoDoes not hold any information relating to this hellip.may have been undertaken by DWP.A copy of the risk-assessment template used by the Department in instances of considering Serious Condition Criteria, was requested, but: ldquoNo template existsInstead, the response referred to assessment procedures where Departmental Healthcare Professionals advise on the re-referral period, and consider whether a claimantrsquos condition meets: ldquoThe new severe conditions criteria andno further assessments are required.However, the claimantrsquos own medical professionalrsquos opinion around Serious Condition Criteria could be over-ruled, with this decided by: ldquoAn Administrative Officer appointed by the Department.In respect of providing the legislation or guidance which permits the Department to overrule clinical opinion provided by a claimant seeking consideration under the Serious Condition Criteria, the response referred to ESA Regulations , which: ldquoProvides for the redetermination of whether someone has limited capability for work. The time period in relation to this is not set down in the legislation but is largely at the Department Decision Makers discretion ndash usually based on available medical evidence including medical reports from ATOS hellip The decision not to reassess those with severe, lelong disabilities or health conditions who would be unlikely to ever move into work, took effect from  September  but did not result in legislative change.As the Freedom of Information request was answerd prior to the restoration of devolution, the Department was asked with a Minister now in post, to comment on current processes around Serious Condition Criteria decision-making and in particular, how it can by discretion supersede a medical diagnosis by a claimantrsquos clinician. It was also askedprocedures are under review andthere is intention to bring forward legislation to allow for scrutiny or challenge.A spokesperson said: ldquo Anyone claiming ESA will be automatically assessed for the Severe Conditions criteria at their Work Capability Assessment by a Healthcare Professional. If the personrsquos condition or its al effects meet the criteria, the Department will be advised that no further assessments are required.In response to the overruling of clinical decisions, the spokesperson said: ldquoThe Work Capability Assessment looks at the al effects of a personrsquos condition, rather than the diagnosis itself. It is not a supersession of the opinion of their clinician.This dfered to the response provided prior to the Minister taking office, which appeared to show the Department was permitted to over-rule the evidence of claimantrsquos clinician.This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: coronavirus lifting covid  restrictions county county not impossible says secretary state
story: Asked when restrictions could be lted, Mr. Lewis said: ldquoThe short answer is I donrsquot know.ldquoWe are going to do a review in three weeksrsquo time. The reality is we will look at the medical evidence. The Northern Ireland Executive will have its own flexibility and we may see across the country some iations we saw some iations going into lockdown as well. Itrsquoll be a decision that all four nations take together based on the evidence, he said.Mr. Lewis said he was aware of the complexities of Northern Irelandrsquos Border with the Republic of Ireland amid the pandemic, explaining that he has been meeting with First Minister Arlene Foster, Deputy First Minister Michelle OrsquoNeill and Taacutenaiste Simon Coveney.ldquoEven where there are dferences in the approach between the Republic and the North,there are,we know that we can make sure we are clear with residents why those dferences are there.ldquoThe challenge of having iations within Northern Ireland is how we manage that.An investigation in The Sunday Times at the weekend featured a Whitehall source claiming the government ldquomissed the boat on testing and PPEand ldquojust watched as the death toll mounted in Wuhan, China.The report also claimed that Prime Minister Boris Johnson missed five crucial COBRA meetings in the Cabinet Office in London.When asked to respond to these serious allegations, Mr. Lewis said: ldquoI didnrsquot recognise some of what I saw in the Times.ldquoI was in the Cobra meetings in January and February COBRA meetings are chaired by the Secretary of State in the Cabinet Office Briefing Rooms. Itrsquos a place, not a thing.ldquoWe were making decisions the scientists and medical experts were making decisions at that time and planning was going on. This is the point to judge it now when we have two months more evidence is dangerous and a misleading thing to do.Turning to PPE which has been an issue in Fermanagh, Mr. Lewis used his own constituency of Great Yarmouth as an example of where there has been ldquono problems with accessing equipment.He added: ldquoWersquove had gowns sent over to the UK, OrsquoNeills [sportswear] converted to gowns, there is gin distillery in your part of the world producing sanitisers.ldquoWersquore shting five and a half million pieces of PPE across to Northern Ireland. Wersquove been able to supply that itrsquos in good order. I am talking to the first minster every day that.Mr. Lewis said the priority of the United Kingdom government is to make sure ldquowe donrsquot hit the second peak of the virus.ldquoOne of the most damaging things economically would be, as well as health wise, to start coming out of lockdown ndash restaurants, pubs, whatever start opening again ndash and suddenly you have to close down again and thatrsquos not viable.ldquoI think itrsquos right to be cautious about this wersquoll make that decision in a few weeks.ldquoThe science is shting on this the experience is changing. I am cautious about predicting what will be in a few weeksrsquo time.He believes the government could ldquoflatten the curve of Covid-people continue to stay at home, adding: ldquoWe want to see past the peak, you donrsquot want to see a downward trend and ease up as all you do is let it shoot back up again.ldquoIf you think back to the beginning there were some quite scary numbers being put about by some experts about what the deaths might be. Now any death is too many and we have sadly lost people, friends and family who have gone through tragic experiences recently, and the figures are nowhere near those numbers we saw at the beginning.ldquoThatrsquos because the public across Northern Ireland and the UK have done a good job generally of following the guidelines which means we can flatten that curve, he said.Mr. Lewis explained that he had personal experience of people close to him who had been diagnosed with Covid-, including his parliamentary private secretary.ldquoSomeone I know lost a member of their family this week, I have a few people in family who had the disease. title: bishop john mcdowell ready take new role
story: Looking forward to his move to Armagh and his new role as the head of the Church of Ireland, he said: ldquoI was obviously surprised and very grateful for the confidence that my colleagues in the House of Bishops placed in me. There is a transition period where you are not really the Archbishop of Armagh but you want to be as helpful as you can and you are also I suppose trying to work out what and how you are going to approach the task.The Archbishop-Elect explained the three facets to the roleHe said there was the appointment of Bishop of the Diocese of Armagh, which has a larger population with a great number of large towns in it than Clogher Diocese.In addition, there is the role of Primacy of All Ireland, considered lsquoFirst among equalsrsquo acknowledging there is another Primate in the southern province but to some degree to be an ambassador for the Church of Ireland.He added: ldquoThe third element is your place within the wider Anglican Communion which I have relatively little experience of. You become a member of the Primatersquos Meeting which is one of the instruments of communion within Anglicanism. There are a number of ways we hold ourselves together, the Lambeth Conference, the office of the Archbishop of Canterbury, the Anglican Consultative Council and more recently, the Primatersquos Meeting.So what type of church do you see under your leadership ldquoItrsquos dficult to speak for the church as the Church of Ireland General Synod is the body which has that authority. There is a saying that the Church of Ireland is synodically governed and episcopally led. What the Archbishop of Armagh can do is to speak to the Church and suggest can concern itself with. It sets a bit of a tone as well. Itrsquos about its spiritual le and its own governance and the need to acknowledge that like probably all institutions and all bodies some bits of it do well and some do not do well some bits are growing and some bits are shrinking some bitsvery well and some bitsnot so well and to maybe try to discover that the bits that do not do well could do a bit better, in terms of spiritual le and acknowledging there is a huge ersity within Anglicanism and to remember that thatrsquos all part of the Anglican heritage.ldquoThere are obviously particularly challenges at the moment, what the church says to society and what it does for the society in which it is placed. You cannot pretend it doesnrsquot live in a political context. Politics is not something that just happens in Parliament. Democracies are places where political discussion or dialogue are about what we can do together or decisions which are deeply embedded. There are institutions which are recognisable bodies in civil society such as the business community, trade unions, voluntary sector and churches are one of those. I think they have their particular things to say and its perfectly legitimate for them to say it.ldquoThe big imponderable at the moment is coronavirus and we have no idea how deeply that will affect the patterns of society. We could come out the other side of that challenge a changed society, with maybe small changes and maybe some very profound changes. Of course the other big external issue is Brexit which involves the relationships between the dferent regions within Ireland and the United Kingdom.ldquoI could be in both parts of that jurisdiction in one day praying for good governance for both of them and for their leaders, he said.In terms of reaching out to people in the Church of Ireland, the Archbishop-Elect recalled how a Northern Ireland Le and Times survey revealed around  per cent of people in Northern Ireland attend church at some point. He said the heyday for attending church was in the period from the late th Century to the period to the middle of the s. But he thinks current attendance is ldquoback to the old norm with fewer people committed to regular churchgoing.He rightly points out that churches are among the very few inter-generational bodies with people of dferent ages attending.The Archdeacon-Elect says people in very small rural parishes are committed to their churches in the sense that they are contributing to their community who feel it is being enriched with their presence. He said the church finds its place in the community.ldquoThe second challenge is what we are for ourselves as a group, as a faith community, how we build up the church, which canrsquot live in isolation but we have our particular family traditions - how we contribute to the ersity of Ireland, how we build up the church to be confident communities of faith and not hesitant or fearful or invisible communities of faith.He said for the Church of Ireland, there was tremendous heritage from Anglicanism.ldquoThe Church of Ireland has a particular way of doing things, liturgically. Liturgy is both the expression and source of our belief. Our vocation may be to hold together what on the face of it appear to be contradictory things is maybe one of our roles in religious and spiritual le. I have no ideait is the best way to be a Christian but it is our way and it seems to contribute something to the catholic church, the wider church.ldquoHarry McAdoo, a well-known Archbishop of Dublin and a great scholar, once said, lsquoIf I hadnrsquot been born an Anglican, I would have had to become one.rsquoThe Archbishop-Elect leaves Clogher Diocese after forging and maintaining good relations with other denominations.He said: ldquoI think the vast majority of committed Christian people see more in common with other Christian traditions than separating us. There is a very long history of ecumenism in the diocese of Armagh as well. There is a long association and friendship with Archbishop Eamon Martin and I hope we can continue to build relationships and friendships.The Archbishop-Elect trained for Church of Ireland ministry after a career in industry in which he held a senior role in Shorts and was for a time, Assistant Director of the CBI in Northern Ireland.ldquoThat probably give me some skills in organisation and about leadership. Irsquove been very lucky here. Irsquom not very fond of the word lsquoleaderrsquo in the ecclesiastical world but one of the things a leader does is to build a team around him. It is almost a contradiction in terms to be involved in a leadership role in Christianity, to do it on your own.ldquoThere are certain things as a bishop that end with you. There are plenty of lonely moments in that sense where you have to make decisions. But by and large business acclimatised me to working with all sorts of dferent people from all sorts of dferent backgrounds in dferent ways and to experience what every parishioner experiences, normal working le with those pressures.As Bishop of Clogher the new Archbishop-Elect held a number of positions nationally and internationally representing the Church.He was the Church of Ireland contact person to the Churches of the Porvoo Communion which represents the Scandanavian and Baltic Lutherans as well as the Spanish and Portuguese Anglicans and other Anglican churches and provinces from these islands making contact at senior level travelling with them.He has also held senior roles on the Irish Council of Churches, the national ecumenical instrument and also the Irish Inter-Church meeting, the latter which includes the Roman Catholic church.He said those bodies were important especially as ecumenism was becoming bland and it was important to keep going and keep talking.These inter-church bodies contribute to providing resources for churches around Brexit, homelessness, welfare reform and subjects churches would be expected to have a voice in.ldquoI enjoyed that hugely, I am coming to the end of that, six years in total two years as vice-President, two years as President and two years as outgoing Vice President. I will be involved again as a member of the Church Leadersrsquo Meeting.The Archbishop-Elect says of his time in Clogher Diocese ldquoItrsquos always been an aim of mine wherever I have worked to try to create a family atmosphere where there are degrees of mutual respect and degrees of mutual accountability. I remember saying that the diocese of Clogher is big enough to do thingswe all pull together in the same direction and small enough for everybody to be necessary for that to happen and to be accountable for what the contribution is. If you treat people with respect, then relationships are easier.ldquoBy and large I felt people were for me rather than against me. It helpsyou are reasonably interested in people and their families and what they do and acknowledge that as an important factor in their faith. Whoever the next Bishop of Clogher is theyshould allow him or her to be his or her own bishop of Clogher and not that they should be like me, Brian Hannon or Michael Jackson or like St. Macartan.The Archbishop-Elect says he enjoys reading history and poetry and in terms of music, takes particular pleasure in the tradition of Anglican anthems . He does admit to particularly enjoying the Psalms which are poetry.The Archbishop-Elect acknowledges that his mother who had a profound influence on his le, reciting the Daily Office at home and was happily committed to God and His Church and would have sung the Te Deum while washing the dishes. One of her favourite biblical phrases was from the Gospel of St. John, Chapter  ldquoI come that you would have le and that you might have it more abundantly.Relaxation for the Archdeacon-Elect is visiting one of his favourite places, the Ulster Museum to see the collection of Irish Art and reading.ldquoThe thing I am looking to reading most is I took possession of the third volume of Hilary Mantelrsquos Wolf Hall trilogy about Thomas Cromwell, lsquoThe Mirror and Light,rsquo an historical novel, he adds.The Archbishop-Electrsquos we Mary teaches in Enniskillen Royal Grammar School and his daughter, Dorothy, is at the University of Oxford.This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. Cattle entries were on a par with last year, and the judges were all impressed with the quality of the calves and the high level of stockmanship.ldquoOur judges have been busy throughout the day, and all were in agreement that the show provides a  for the provincersquos pedigree beef champions of tomorrow.
