title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. Street to the Tabernacle church on Plassey Street, where volunteers have more space to follow social distancing rules.ldquoAt the moment wersquore running with three volunteers a day, said Claire.ldquoWersquore asking for people to come with a list of what they need and one of our volunteers will go into the church and collect what wersquove got to address those specic needs.Claire and the team are currently getting ready for a surge in requirements as the epidemic escalates.ldquoWe are expecting that as things start to bite, we will be seeing more people who have lost jobs and whorsquos circumstances have changed because of the virus, said Claire.ldquoWe are mostly supported by the other churches in Penarth where food arrives every week but obviously because theyrsquove had to close their services, wersquore not going to be having that big weekly drop-off.ldquoHowever, people have been bringing stuff constantly, so itrsquos great.ldquoFolk from all over the community are dropping stuff in- even loo paper!ldquoIf any of us are ill there are lots of people who can step into our place. Providing that people continue to be generous then there wonrsquot be a problem.As increasing numbers of people self-isolate to protect themselves from the virus, Claire said that the food bank was able to offer deliveriesnecessary.ldquoWe are a very open foodbank. If yoursquove got a need, just ask and we can do our best, said Claire.After the Church in Wales announced the suspension of public acts of worship, the Tabernacle and other churches in Penarth have been finding innovative ways to support their congregation.ldquoFrom this weekend we are going to be streaming virtual services, said Clair.ldquoOur musicians are recording pieces in their homes which will be shared online.ldquoAll our small groups meet on Zoom so wersquore in touch with our congregation.ldquoThe more elderly congregations are keeping in touch by phone and telephone to support them in every way ndash spiritually, emotionally and practically.ldquoThe epidemic is pulling everybody together and cutting across denominational boundaries.The Tabernacle Foodbank is open for donations and collections between am and pm Monday to Friday.You can also deliver donations to their collection point in Sainsburyrsquos on Windsor Road.The foodbank would particularly welcome tinned products, including curry, chilli, corned beef, and potatoes.For more information, visit: Info@tabspenarth or call:  . article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: local photographer leaves picture along coastal path make people smile isolation
story: Rock pools along the coast by Rochelle Gough" Local photographer leaves pictures along coastal path to make people smile during isolationOne of the prints discovered by a local walker " Local photographer leaves pictures along coastal path to make people smile during isolationA message of thanks on Instagram " Local photographer leaves pictures along coastal path to make people smile during isolationRochelle admires the sunsets on the coast at Sully " Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentAN AMATEUR photographer has placed pictures along the coastal path between her home in Sully and Cardf Bay as a way of raising peoplersquos spirits during lock-down.If you were walking along the coast in Sully this weekend, you might have found a strange cylindrical parcel propped up against a wall or laying on a bench.Stooping to pick it up, you would see that someone had written a message on its side: ldquoFree photograph inside to cheer someone up during this strange time.Your curiosity piqued, you would open the parcel and find a picture of the sky reflected upon a rock pool, or a line of trees with autumnal boughs sweeping down towards the ground.These enigmatic prints were left along the path by Rochelle Gough, , an amateur photographer who wanted to connect with her community and reach out to those who might be struggling in isolation.ldquoI do photography as a hobby, explained Rochelle. ldquoI had a few prints left over and I thought that instead of them collecting dust I would post them along the coastal path between Sully and Cardf Bay.ldquoIrsquove been living in Sully all my le. Irsquove grown up on the beach.ldquoI normally take landscape pictures because I love the water and some of the sunsets here are incredible, especially in the winter.Rochelle wrote her Instagram handle on the parcels, so that people who found them could send her a message.ldquoIt was just to make someone smile, and Irsquove had some lovely comments from people who got back to me on Instagram, she said.ldquoThey said they were going to put it up in their room and frame it.ldquoSome people were feeling a bit down and didnrsquot expect to find anything, so it cheered them up.ldquoMy job was done ndash the main purpose was to make people smile and it did - it made me smile too.ldquoI think itrsquos very important to say hello, especiallypeople are living by themselves orthey havenrsquot got their family around.ldquoWhen Irsquom normally walking the dog I say hello and have a chat, but itrsquos quite hard to do that now because everyone is quite wary.ldquoI donrsquot have to have that physical contact with someone to brighten up their day.ldquoArt is just a dferent  to communicate with. You knowsomeonersquos a bit shy and they donrsquot want to speak using words, they may want to draw a picture and open up that way instead.ldquoI think art can show feelings that words canrsquot quite express, so itrsquos a great idea to share that with the community.At a time of uncertainty and doubt, Rochelle ended with a message of hope and solidarity:ldquoI think as a community we could do so much more at this time, she saidldquoEveryone is concerned about how long it is going to last, but I am hopeful we can get past it, andwe all work together and remain positive we may come out of this in an even better situation than we was before.Rochelle would like to make clear that all parcels were fully sanitised. title: students stay happy healthy
story: The Penarth school has  young people who are currently living between four residential homes on the site while the school closes to all others except the children of key workers.Vice-principal to government advice on social distancing and hygiene we are doing a huge range of activities to ensure healthy bodies and minds including trampolining, painting, baking cakes and starting the day grounds.ldquoIt is critical we maintain a routine and stimulate the students through this challenging period.ldquoThe staff have responded with characteristic passion and dedication to provide a safe and happy home for our young people.Alan, , a resident student, said: ldquoThe news has been very frightening, but I have felt very safe at the school.ldquoThe staff have really looked after us and title: cardiff south penarth mp stephen doughty calls keir starmers labour leadership win ray hope difficult times
story: The MP for Holborn and St Pancras defeated Lisa Nandy and Rebecca Long-Baily.Mr Doughty has previously expressed his support for Sir Keir, who won on the first round of voting with . per cent of ballots cast.Stephen called Sir Keirs ascension a ray of hope, and said that the party should now turn its attention to winning elections.He said: ldquoI am so pleased that Keir Starmer has become UK Labour leader.ldquoThe ray of hope Keir represents could not come at a more critical time.ldquoHis message of unity has won over members up and down the country ndash and we need to ensure that we model that through the whole of the UK Labour Party.ldquoAnd it is clear that Labour comes out of this contest stronger, with Rebecca and Lisa running really positive campaigns.ldquoThe UK General Election result in December was devastating for Labour and we cannot repeat it."Thatrsquos why Keirrsquos campaign was all about focussing the party on winning elections. Only then can we change peoplersquos lives."Welsh Labour, and First Minister Mark Drakeford will now be working closely with Keir to ensure we win the Senedd elections next year.ldquoKeir has already shown his commitment to Wales and Welsh Labour, and personally visited Cardf South and Penarth with me just a few months ago to meet local residents.ldquoWe also need to restore peoplersquos trust in the Labour Party as a force for good - a crucial part of that is tackling antisemitism."I know that Keir has the values, vision and moral compass needed to fight for justice at home and abroad ndash and that is needed more than ever.ldquoNobody could have predicted the campaign ending in these hugely dficult circumstances - and regardless of the result, our primary thoughts at the moment are with all those affected by coronavirus, and our brilliant NHS and social care staff, and key workers up and down the country who are keeping us going and saving lives every day."The Labour Partyrsquos number one priority right now is working across party lines to help the country get through this.ldquoI am also delighted Angela Rayner has been elected our new UK Deputy Leader ndash someone who I have campaigned with on a range of issues over many years. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentsSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: virus decimated marie curie hospice charity income penarth
story: End of le patients who do not want to be in hospital need to be moved to a more appropriate setting, as beds in critical care units are urgently required for patients who need lesaving treatment.The charity, which relies upon public donations and fundraising events needs to raise pound million a year to continue to run its essential frontline services across Wales.However, chief executive Matthew Reed has said the charityrsquos income has been lsquodecimatedrsquo due to the outbreak.Rachel Moses-Lloyd from Marie Curie in Wales said: ldquoWhen the NHS and public need us most, we are facing huge dficulties raising our vital funds."Along with the cancellation of hundreds of high street and supermarket collections, wersquore now losing income from the closure of our charity shops and from cancelled fundraising events."The Marie Curie Cardf and the Vale Hospice in Penarth cares for around , people each year.Its manager, Sarah Lloyd-Davies, said: ldquoAcross Marie Curie we have provided care to a few terminally ill patients who have tested positive for coronavirus or are suspected of having it and do expect this to continue in future. For reasons of patient confidentiality we are not able to discuss specic cases of care from the hospice or from the community nursing care we provide.ldquoOur hospice staff and nursing teams across Cardf and the Vale are very much on the frontline and have an important job in keeping patients out of hospital to relieve pressure on the NHS. That is important now more than ever given the coronavirus crisis. The health and wellbeing of our patients, their loved ones, and our staff is our top priority and across the hospice and community we are taking steps to protect them. This includes the use of PPE and, in-line with other providers of care, including the NHS, we have amended our visiting rules at the hospice.ldquoWith regards PPE, unfortunately, our hospice and community nursing service have been facing the same issues as the NHS in terms of getting all the equipment they need. We are screening patients with a phone call before attending their homes and staff will wear the appropriate PPE equipment during every household visit. However, we can only do this when we have the right PPE equipment available and are grateful to have recently received support from our colleagues at the Cardf and the Vale University Health Board to gain access to some PPE through their supply, for which we give our thanks.ldquoHowever we are always in need of more supplies to continue to provide vital end of le care to people living with a terminal illness, especially at this dficult time. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: coronavirus  cases vale glamorgan lock extended
story: A total of  of these cases were in the Vale of Glamorgan where a further  people tested positive on Wednesday.In total  people have been tested for the virus in the Vale, of whom . per cent have tested positive.Meanwhile, the virus has claimed  more lives across Wales, meaning  have now passed away with the disease.There were  new cases of covid- reported in Wales, taking the total number of confirmed cases to ,, although the true number of cases is likely to be higher.Dr Robin Howe, Incident Director for the Novel Coronavirusoutbreak response at Public Health Wales, said: ldquoWe offer our condolences to families and friends affected, and we ask those reporting on the situation to respect patient confidentiality.ldquoPublic Health Wales has conducted more than , tests for Novel Coronaviruson more than , iniduals since the start of this outbreak.It comes as a Welsh Government minister said lockdown rules will continue into at least next week.When the UK-wide lockdown rules were announced, prime minister Boris Johnson said they would be reviewed every three weeks.Next Monday, April , marks three weeks since the announcement.But, speaking at a press conference yesterday, the Welsh Government housing and local government minister Julie James said this was too soon to lt the lockdown and the rules would remain in force in Wales into the start of next week - and possibly further.A more formal announcement on the continuation of lockdown guidelines will be given soon."These are extraordinary times, and weve taken these measures because by working together we can slow the speed of the coronavirus," Mrs James said."We will definitely be extending the guidelines, and more formal restrictions will be announced within the next few days. What I do know is that the measures will definitely stay in force after Monday."With the Easter weekend coming up, Mrs James also reiterated the importance of abiding by the rules."There are signs that these measures are having an impact," she said. "Our decisions taken this weekend will impact our lives in the future. title: food vouchers sent   parents vale glamorgan
story: Though schools in the Vale have been closed for normal lessons since Monday March , many continued providing free meals.But it was later discovered that only a small faction of these were being claimed.Now the parents of the  Vale pupils in receipt of free school meals have been sent vouchers, which can be used to purchase food from a local supermarket.Arrangements were put in place for Tesco and Asda vouchers to be distributed and it is hoped a similar system can be established with other food outlets, including smaller operators located in the rural Vale.Parents will receive a pound voucher every fortnight, which equates to  school meals worth pound. for each eligible child.Councillor Lis Burnett, Vale of Glamorgan Council Cabinet Member for Regeneration and Education, said: ldquoI have been immensely proud of the way council staff have responded to such dficult circumstances and there is no better example of that than within our Learning and Skills teams.ldquoIn just two days staff working there have established a completely new system for administering free school meal provision so that no child goes without.ldquoSetting up this voucher system will help ensure a great many more children get the meals they are entitled to as only a small proportion were recently being claimed from schools.ldquoThe need to develop this system so quickly inevitably means there will be some fine tuning along the way.ldquoWith that in mind, I would ask parents to let us knowthey experience any glitches in the system and thank them for their patience and appreciation of the dficult circumstances our staff are working in.For more information on changes to school services, visit the Vale Council website. article_url   content_id   site_id title: cardiff south penarth mp stephen doughty calls international cooperation tackle coronavirus new labour frontbench role
story: The MP for Cardf South and Penarth will work alongside the Shadow Foreign Secretary, Lisa Nandy, as a joint Shadow Foreign Office and International Development Minister for the African continent.He was previously appointed as Shadow Minister for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs until he resigned from the position in .During his live daily Q and A session yesterday, Mr Doughty said: "I got a call from the Sir Kier Starmer yesterday letting me know hed like me to be a Shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs and International Development."Ill be working in two dferent teams with Lisa Nandy and Preet Kaur Gill - both fantastic people and Im delighted to be working with them."And the full front bench team was announced today so it will be a delight to go back and be in a shadow ministerial role."Its something that I feel Ive got a lot to contribute on but also is going to be so crucial because were seeing the impacts that coronavirus is having in this country with a developed health system with relatively strong levels of support for people, though I appreciate at the moment its incredibly dficult for people but compared to some countries around the world who literally dont have any of the type of equipment or expertise or staffing that we do in our health service."Im really fearful of some of the impact that will have in some of the poorest countries around the world, so this is undoubtedly going to be a big issue over the next few months and Im going to be working very closely with Kiers team to make sure we get the right support from governments across the world working together because were not going to solve this crisis by putting up barriers."Sir Keir won the Labour leadership contest in the first round of voting at a ballot last week, where he competed against Lisa Nandy and Rebecca Long-Baily.Mr Doughty has previously expressed his support for Sir Keir and called his victory a ray of hope. article_url   content_id   site_id title: cafe offers delivery service help need
story: Staff at the Marie Curie Hospice in Penarth" Café offers delivery service to help those in needCharlotte Court , co-owner of Willmore#s , delivers food parcels ltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtto Llandough lt spangtlt spangt" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentA LOCAL cafeacute has started a regular food delivery service to support frontline staff and their patients who are suffering from Covid- at Llandough Hospital.The co-owners of Willmorersquos  on Stanwell Road, Matthew Holland and Charlotte Court, have delivered over  meals to frontline facilities in Penarth since the beginning of the pandemic, including the Marie Curie Hospice on Bridgeman Road.Now the pair have plans to extend their operations.They have raised over pound for the charitable cause, which includes money collected in a fundraiser by the community support group, Helping Hands Penarth.ldquoWe closed the shop three weeks ago and used all the leftover stock to do the first delivery to the hospital, explained Matthew.ldquoWersquove all got to be doing something and we felt like we had to utilize the shop and give something back to the guys that are putting their lives at risk.ldquoPenarth is a really small town and yoursquove just got to try and support each other as much as possible.ldquoI think yoursquove got to step up and do as much as you can,you can. Wersquove got the capacity to do it.Matthew went on to describe the atmosphere at Llandough Hospital.ldquoWersquore both in Penarth and wersquove lived here all our lives. Its important to us that we support it as much as possible.ldquoIts uplting being able to do that. It was so emotional being able to see the nurses on the Covid ward.ldquoFor me and Charlotte it was very humbling because those guys are putting their lives at risk and theyrsquore asking for stuff for patients, not for themselves.ldquoWe were quite tearful because we didnrsquot want to leave them there ndash but theyrsquore doing it day in-day out without batting an eyelid. story: Irsquove also recorded online conversations with council leaders and police, and these are available to view on my page at any time. title: strategy announced lead wales lockdown
story: The framework will help to determine when the strict stay-at-home restrictions can begin to be relaxed in Wales and will help to find a way for people in Wales to live and work alongside coronavirus.A Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing is being developed through the office of the Chief Medical Officer, Dr Frank Atherton. This will highlight the importance of community testing and support the containment of emerging coronavirus infections as and when restrictions are eased.Launching the framework, the First Minister said: ldquoOur approach to date has been one of lockdown. We have taken unprecedented steps to protect everyone, but particularly those most at risk from serious illness.ldquoThis has helped the NHS prepare and cope with coronavirus and, even though we have sadly seen more than  people die, it has helped to save many more lives. But this strategy comes with its own costs to peoplersquos wider health and wellbeing and long-term costs to our economy.ldquoWe are keeping these regulations under constant review. We know coronavirus will be with us for a long time yet but we want to see whether there are things we can do while we continue to tackle the virus and while the search for better treatments and a vaccine continue.The framework ndash and the seven questions ndash will help determine when the time is right to relax some of the stay-at home regulations.The seven questions are:bull Would easing a restriction have a negative effect on containing the virus bull Does a particular measure pose a low risk of further infection bull How can it be monitored and enforced bull Can it be reversed quicklyit creates unintended consequences bull Does it have a positive economic benefit bull Does it have a positive impact on peoplersquos wellbeing bull Does it have a positive impact on equality The Chief Medical Officer for Walesrsquo office has developed the Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing.It will have four main strands ndash improved surveillance of cases of coronavirus effective identication of cases and contact tracing learning from international experience and engaging with the public.Dr Atherton said: ldquoAction to ease the lockdown restrictions will need to be supported by a comprehensive public health response, which will need to developed quickly and at scale.ldquoAcross the UK, we have worked and put in place unprecedented measures to contain and delay the spread of coronavirus. We have also worked to reduce the overall impact of the virus by strengthening essential services, including healthcare.ldquoWe are now working towards a new recovery phase to lead us out of the pandemic but only when the conditions are right.The First Minister added: ldquoCoronavirus is not going to disappear ndash it is likely it will be with us for a long time. We will need to have some sort of restrictions in place for some time yet to continue to control the spread of the virus and reduce community transmission. This framework will help us determine what is right for Wales.ldquoThere is a long road ahead of us towards recovery to pre-pandemic levels, butwe continue to work together, I hope we will be able to make changes to the restrictions and see a gradualto something resembling normal le.The Welsh Government has worked closely with the rest of the UK throughout the pandemic and has shared the development of the framework with the Scottish, Northern Irish and the UK governments. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: governments five key lockdown tests met
story: But what progress has been made  And how far off is Britain from the targets Test . The NHS has the capacity to provide critical care right across the UKThe first test is whether Britain has the capacity to look after those seriously ill with coronavirus ndash which can be measured by spare beds in intensive care.Hospitals have not been overwhelmed by patients so far in the pandemic, and in some places have been aided by the opening of the new NHS Nightingales.Health Secretary Matt Hancock said on Monday that there were , spare critical care beds in the health service, and that in most parts of the country, the number of people in hospital with coronavirus is beginning to fall.This test, therefore, appears to have been met. vw,vw,px, px"The number of people eligible for tests has been widened in recent days Test . A sustained and consistent fall in daily deaths from coronavirusScientists estimate that Englandrsquos daily hospital death toll peaked around April , and it has been very steadily falling since.However, the picture is less clear when deaths in the community are included, with some suggestions that deaths in care homes may still be increasing.More data is needed to be clear whether this test has been met. vw,vw,px, px"Test . The rate of infection decreased to manageable levels across the boardThe lsquoRrsquo value ndash or infection rate ndash is now thought to be somewhere between . and , meaning that each person infected with the virus passes it on to less than one other person.This in turn means the total number of cases is falling. But,R rises above , there could be another exponential rise in infections.It is likely this test has been met across the board, but the Government will be extremely anxious to ensure the rate of infection does not rise again. vw,vw,px, px"Test . Operational challenges including testing and PPE are in hand with supply able to meet future demandThe Government remains a long way off its target of testing , people a day by the end of the month, with just , tests carried out on Sunday ndash though the number is increasing daily.And while more than a billion items of personal protective equipmenthave been distributed, concerns over shortages remain ndash particularly among care home staff.Given the global spread of the disease, operational challenges in sourcing PPE may continue for some time. So far, this test does not appear to have been met. vw,vw,px, px"Concerns have been raised over medical and care home staff facing shortages of some items of PPE Test . Confident that any adjustments to the current measures will not risk a second peak of infectionsPrime Minister Boris Johnson said on Monday that he would not risk a second peak in the disease by relaxing restrictions too quickly.But Downing Street came in for questioning a day later when it published its ldquofive tests document with altered wording, leading to speculation the Government is preparing to ease the lockdown restrictions.Rather than stating that ministers had to be confident an adjustment would not ldquorisk a second peak of infections, the wording was changed to say no weakening of restrictions would be made that would risk a second peak that ldquooverwhelms the NHS.Health Secretary Matt Hancock said during the Number  press conference on Tuesday that the NHS had coped with the first peak of infections, which is thought to have occurred around Easter.The Governmentrsquos scientic advisers are presenting a series of options to ministers about easing lockdown title: potential covid  treatments fast tracked new initiative
story: Six drugs will initially enter the programme being set up under the Accelerating Covid- Research  Development.The Department of Health and Social Caresaid its aim is to accelerate the development of drugs for patients admitted to hospital with coronavirus and reduce the time it takes to set up clinical studies from months to just weeks.The DHSC said the first of the potential drugs is beginning phase  studies across the UK ldquoimminently, the point at which a clinical trial focuses on testing a drug on patients to assess its effectiveness and any side effects.Announcing the new initiative, Health Secretary Matt Hancock said: ldquoCurrently, no drugs in the world have been clinically proven to treat Covid-.ldquoBut our Therapeutics Taskforce has identied a number of promising candidates.ldquoCurrently, six dferent treatments have been entered into national clinical trials and the first is ready to enter the next stage: a new early phase clinical trial  that we are launching today.Early indications of drugsrsquo positive results under the Accord programme, which is funded by the DHSC and UK Research and Innovation , will see them rapidly advance to large-scale trials.The first wave of new and existing medicines to be tested through the Accord  are: Bemcetinib, MEDI and Acalabrutinib.Further potential treatments will be fed into Accord as the programme rolls out over the next few weeks.It has been formed through a partnership between the Government Scientic Office, the National Institute for Health Research rsquos biomedical research centres and clinical research facilities, and expert centres in Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales, clinical research company IQVIA and biopharmaceutical company AstraZeneca.It comes under the overall work of the Therapeutic Taskforce, to whom the le science sector can suggest potential drugs or molecules that could be tested through the Accord .Business Secretary Alok Sharma said: ldquoThe UK is home to world-class scientists and researchers who are united in their aim to defeat coronavirus.ldquoThrough Accord, we are bringing together the Government, industry and research organisations to speed up the development of effective new coronavirus treatments, helping to save thousands of peoplersquos lives and benefiting our NHS.Tim Sheppard, IQVIA UK general manager and senior vice president northern Europe, said: ldquoCovid- is the greatest public health challenge that has faced the world in a generation.ldquoHyper-accelerating clinical trials of medicines in discovery pipelines could be title: cemeteries decision welcomed
story: Man escapes blazing lorry cab on NI roadNI Council spends £k to fight court ruling to reveal ‘secret’ documentNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPoliticsCemeteries decision welcomedA Portadown councillor and grieving mother, has welcomed the news cemeteries across Northern Ireland have reopened.By The NewsroomMonday, th April , : pm""Kernan Cemetery. INPT-. : -TONY HENDRONNNAs a result of COVID- lockdown measures, cemeteries were closed to the public in March. However, on Friday, April th the legislation was changed.Now, cemeteries operated by Northern Ireland’s  councils are allowed to open, provided they implement measures to ensure social distancing.Reflecting on the announcement, Ulster Unionist Party councillor, Julie Flaherty, who lost her two-year-old son in  said: “The fact the Executive has listened to grieving families and shown compassion on this issue will be greeted with relief by many people, myself included.“You all know by now, that I know from personal, painful experience just how important it is to be able to visit the resting place of a loved one in order to gain a degree of peace and solace.“Reopening graveyards is not just a compassionate decision, it is the right decision.The Portadown councillor also urged those attending graveyards to follow the strict social distancing guidelines in place.“This should not be viewed as a sign of complacency – this was just the right thing to do at the right time,” said Cllr Flaherty.“There is still strict guidances in place. Social distancing is vital now in every aspect of our lives.“The NI Executive guidance remains in place for funerals so please be aware that when a funeral is taking place the regulations have not changed regarding times and the number of mourners present, the cemetery will be closed for visitors during funerals.“This should not be a problem – common courtesy, manners and dignity usually prevails when visiting a cemetery at any time for those of us who must.”Commenting on the decision by the Executive to allow cemeteriesto reopen, a spokesperson for Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council said: “As a council we welcome the announcement by the NI Assembly to change the Health ProtectionRegulations Northern Ireland Act .“We are acutely aware of the deep sensitivities surrounding the closures therefore all cemeteries will reopen…with the necessaryguidance in place to ensure visitor and staff safety.”In a statement, the Lord Mayor of Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council, Councillor Mealla Campbell said: “I welcome the decision by the NI Executive to reopen cemeteries.“This has been a very dficult and emotional time for many people in our community who have lost loved ones. I know this decision will bring some comfort to people who are grieving and have been unable to visit their loved ones place of rest for several weeks.“All council owned cemeteries will now be opened in line with public health advice and I encourage people to please maintain safe social distancing during this time.”The Council has advised that during this time, visitors are asked to: follow Public Health Authorityadvice on social distancing accommodatefuneral services by leaving cemeteriesasked to do so by staff and, be aware thatcemetery gatesare locked, during normal opening times, this is due to funeral preparation.The DUP’s group leader, Councillor Mark Baxter said his party welcome the decision.“As a party we are glad that the cemeteries are now open,” he said.“All our council representatives were contacted many times by distressed families who were unable to visit the graves of their loved ones .“We feel that social distancing is quite easily achieved within these facilities and on balance it’s a much better position to be in as a local authority to have them open.”Speaking to the Local Democracry Reporting Service, Sinn Fein MLA John O’Dowd said the party recognises “the comfort visiting the grave of a loved one can bring”.“The opening of of cemeteries will be permitted where compliance with regulations and social distancing can be adhered to,” said the Upper Bann MLA.“Sinn Fein recognises the comfort visiting the grave of loved one can bring. We have listenedto the distress of families who have been unable to visit those graves.“We are not through crisis however, so Sinn Fein continue to ask people to stay at home and to only go outabsolutely necessary.”Adam Morton , Local Democracy Reporting Service""Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-bEjcJn boXdXt"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-fOICqy kfiVLF"Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-bEjcJn boXdXt"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-fOICqy kfiVLF"This website and its associated newspaper are members of Independent Press Standards Organisation Follow us onExploreNewsSportWhats OnLestyleMore from Portadown TimesAnnouncementsJobsPublic NoticesMust ReadBuy a PhotoDirectoryLocal GuideReader ShopUseful LinksContact UsAdvertise My BusinessAdvertise a JobPlace your AdSubscribeEventsArchiveReaders Charter" fill"#ea"©JPIMedia Publishing Ltd. ." target"_self" href"#" id"cookieSettings" class"sc-bYSBpT sc-elJkPf kHpvMx"Cookie SettingsTerms and ConditionsPrivacy policyNews" class"expand" role"button" tabindex""""" scale translate " points"  .  . title: dup calling special meeting armagh banbridge and craigavon council discuss amenity sites
story: ASDA announces fundraising campaignDUP calling for special meeting of Armagh, Banbridge and Craigavon Council to discuss amenity sitesNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPoliticsDUP calling for special meeting of Armagh, Banbridge and Craigavon Council to discuss amenity sitesDUP representatives on ArmaghCity, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council have urged the Council’s Lord Mayor to call a special meeting.By The NewsroomMonday, th April , : amUpdated Monday, th April , : pm""Lord Mayor Mealla Campbell : FreelanceUnder the Council’s standing order . the Lord Mayor must call a meeting of the Councila request for such a meeting is supported by nine members of the chamber.The standing order also states thatthe Lord Mayor refuses or does not call the meeting within seven day of service of the request, then the nine members may call a meeting of the Council at the expiration of this period.The DUP has  members on Council and wants the meeting to discuss the COVID- pandemic within the borough.Writing to the Council’s Lord Mayor, Councillor Mealla Campbell, the DUP’s group whip, Cllr Darryn Causby said: “I have been instructed by all  of my party colleagues to request that you call a special meeting of the Council to discuss the current COVID- situation.“In particular to discuss the issues relating to amenity sites. I am requesting this meeting under standing order . Convening Special Meetings.“I would ask that you accede to this request as soon as possible. We note however, thatyou do not accede to this request within seven days we have the power, under the same standing order to call a meeting ourselves.”Cllr Causby continued: “Additionally, we understand that Council are working to provide a technology based solution to Council meetings. However, four weeks have now passed our Council has not met.“Given that the NI Assembly and the WestminsterParliament are still meeting, we believe that as with the previous special meeting, appropriate social distancing measures can be put in place and a meeting should take place in the WJ Mayes Hall.“It is our view that the full Council should be meeting at this crucial time as it is the elected members who are responsible for the direction and decisions being made for the organisation.“Party leaders meetings are good forums for discussion but they are not a placefor making decisions and we respectfully request that members are allowed to fulfiltheir democratic duty to govern the borough.”A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: marts to reopen gradually
story: THE Department for Agriculture, Environment and Ruralaffairs has welcomed the decision by the Northern Ireland Livestock and Auctioneers’ Associationto open Livestock Marts on a gradual basis from Monday,  April.Livestock Marts closed voluntarily on  March - including Rathfriland Co-Op and Hilltown Saleyard - in response to Covid- health and safety concerns. Recently mart operators trialled a number of successful online sales to enable livestock trading to continue and are now gradually moving towards re-opening on a phased basis from next Monday, with some restrictions in place.In welcoming the decision, a spokesman said: “Farmers are key workers and are continuing to provide food for us all in very challenging circumstances. Part of that food supply chain is the ability to trade and sell animals.“Staff within the Department have maintained regular contact with Livestock Mart operators over recent weeks and have been reassured that robust operational protocols, developed by the Marts in conjunction with other stakeholders, will enable them to conduct business in a manner that is safe for staff, farmers and buyers and adheres to social distancing requirements.“DAERA therefore welcomes the decision to recommence sales of primestock, cull animals and store stock on a gradual basis from week commencing  April.
